title: China vs USA WSDC 2018 Round 6
description:
The decision in this debate was a 2-1 win for China. 

The motion was : This house would not allow sellers and service providers to advertise their products beyond showing information and images that reveal technical product details.

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: THW not allow sellers and services providers to advertise their products beyond showing information and images that reveal technical product details.

argument_units.text: Maurice Cotill from Greece, and Christopher Sanchez from Germany. I now invite the first speaker for self-proposition to open the debate. For far too long, advertisements have been preying on the insecurities of people by creating a stereotype that makes people feel inadequate and unable to live a good life if they cannot

buy into that stereotype and purchase that product. Proposition wants to free consumers from the constructed stereotypes by advertisement and restore consumer agencies and make consumption decisions that they think are best for themselves. First, let's talk about our model. Four things.

First, we would ban sellers and service providers from revealing any additional information other than technical details on things like the internet, TV, the billboard, or packaging of the product. Second, what do we mean by technical details? We say those are details that are relevant to the functionality of the product, which means if it's an electronic product, it means things like the electronic capacities, the processors, the

function of the phone, capacities, the processors, the function of the phone, what are the applications in the phone. If it's a morning club, we say something about its functions, its ingredients, but without putting it on people like celebrities like Rihanna or putting it on models. Thirdly, we say Google cancel all brand names and rather give every product a product ID number and make them to be all packaged in plain white box with technical details written on the box.

Fourthly, we say we are okay with things like political advertising or promoting feminist messages that appear on TV because they are different from consumer advertising which the aim is to sell a certain product instead of sell a certain ideology, as we see in the political campaign and feminist campaign. In my speech, two things.

First, I'm going to tell you why advertisements beyond tacticality lead to the exploitation of people's insecurities and why that's bad. Second, why we enable more competition and innovation that ultimately will benefit consumers.
My second speaker will tell you how we benefit social change. Before I move on, yes?

Would you ban Delta Airlines from running ads about the charity work they do in sub-Saharan Africa because it's separate from the product? No, we simply say that it's not in the debate because in this debate we're talking about selling a certain product that you want people to buy. Rather, when you're talking about charities, they're aiming to help a certain group of people instead of selling a certain product that you want people to buy. Rather, when you're talking about charities, they're aiming to help a certain group of people instead of selling a certain product.

Coming to the first thing, why advertisement beyond technicality leads to exploitation? Let's be very clear about the context. We're living in a world with greater consumerism, which means that people are likely to purchase things not necessarily because they need those things, but because they want them. And most of the times, our desire for a certain product is manufactured by producers because they market their products in a way that ties the product to your own identities. Which means, if you don't buy a certain product, you will feel inadequate or a holding out of your identity and ultimately and these to a coercion for consumers to feel that they need more products they

have to buy a certain product what are the harms of this three things first we say it disproportionately for women and minorities why is that so two reasons structural incentive structural incentive of advertisers is you pander to the existing power structure, things like patriarchy, or the majority who have more political and financial power, as we see in examples of De Beers, which is a South African wedding ring company which marketed to men to say that if you buy a certain ring, you will have greater chances of having sex with a woman. We say those are all things that objectifies women and something we reject.

Second, even if we're not talking about their pandering to existing power structures, most of the advertisers have the incentive to create and manufacture a new stereotype that they want people to buy into. And these are things that are explicit in things like brand loyalty by saying that if you want to live to a certain life standard, you should always buy a fancy watch or go to a fancy restaurant. And explicitly do that by asking a celebrity to eat in your fancy restaurant and put that advertisement on TV. The second thing we think is harmful is because it disproportionately harms the poor. Why is that so? Because first, advertisement exclusively creates a consumerist lifestyle, which makes your self-worth to what you can purchase or what you can buy in life. Why is that harmful? Because the poor in the status quo have less purchasing power, which means that they're less likely to buy, to fulfill that kind of lifestyle, and thus they will feel less self-worth simply because they cannot buy that fancy product. We give you the example of how a Chinese student sells his kidney in order to buy a new iPhone because of the pernicious impact of consumerism that he thinks that no matter at what cost, he should get that new version of iPhone.

But thirdly, those kind of harms are not limited just for the poor. They are harming everyone in society, including the middle class and the rich, simply because of the reason that it creates consumerism. Why is consumerism bad? Two reasons. First, because what we need to recognize is that everything is a zero-sum game, which means that the more you can get directly leads to the less the other person can get. This means that if we have a consumerist society, we will never have a scenario in which everyone is happy with their life, in which everyone will feel a kind of meaning tied to their life. You're always going to harm a group of people. Second, because we say they're making life as it leads to an end, which is consumerism, rather than an end in itself. What does it mean? We give the example of a lot of people who would choose jobs that will give them more pay instead of jobs that they actually love. We give the example because people are more likely to choose jobs that make better pay as they can get more money and reach the consumer's goal that the society is pushing forward this narrative. But fourthly, we say we're going to create their argument

that it can never regulate this kind of problem simply because most of the advertisements and their stereotypes are subtle and subconscious. Which means you cannot quantify and you do not know what are the impacts of the advertisement on consumers. You can never regulate something that you cannot quantify and you do not know the exact impact.

So how does our side change this? By two ways. First, we break the bond between the brand and the product, which means that we break things like brand loyalty. Now people are no longer confined by brand loyalty or the rigid stereotype provided by a certain brand. Second, we encourage rational consumption, which means that now consumers are going to evaluate a product only based on its functionality or the specification of the product rather than thinking of whether I can seem more wealthy if I buy this product. Why is that a good thing? Very simple. Because first, if you make more rational choices, it means better management of your personal finance. Second, because we allow people to find alternative sources of their life worth or of their life meaning instead of being hinged upon consumerism.

Now, coming to the second thing, why we enable more competition and innovation. There are two problems in the status quo. First, we say there is a disparity between wealthy and poor companies, which means that wealthy companies have more access to the avenues of advertisement. They can build brand loyalty. They have more power to construct the stereotype for consumers. And the mechanism of change is that we make it equal, we equalize the playing field by allowing companies to compete with each other based on the technicalities or the functions of their products. That's how we allow things like startups with very little initial brand loyalty or very little access to advertisement to change. Second problem we identified in the status quo is that advertisement often serves as a mask for low-quality products or products that does not actually have the innovative traits that the companies advertise for. We give the example of iPhones. When they get a new iPhone, they probably do not have a lot of innovations, but they brand it or they market it to have a lot of innovations. And it's the judgment of consumers.

In the end, we benefit consumers because we create more creation and innovation in the market. We give them better choices, we give them higher quality products we're so proud to propose. Thank you. Okay. Okay, so I'd like to thank the speaker speaker of side proposition for delivering their speech, and

we'd like to invite the first speaker of the other. When Delta runs an advertisement talking about its charity work building medical clinics in sub-Saharan Africa, or when Dove runs the Like a Girl campaign that empowers women to pursue things that most people think are just for men, or even when Audi runs an advertisement talking about how their company recently implemented a policy to ensure that there are both men and women working for the company, they aren't doing that because they really just want to share with people what great things their company is doing. They are doing that in order to promote their brand and sell products.

When side proposition tells you that they would allow companies to do things like this on their side of the house, that is a round losing concession because they acknowledge that all of these things are legitimate things for people to consider when making decisions about what sorts of products to buy. That is the core question in this round. It is absolutely a right that we support and it's why side proposition loses today's debate.

Before I introduce some rebuttal to side proposition material and talk about our first two substantive arguments, I'd just like to clarify a couple of things in this round. First, our side would not allow things like false advertising. If a company actively lies about something that their product does, like cigarette companies lying about the health effects of their products, we obviously wouldn't allow that on our side of the house. But second, again, the core question in today's debate is, is product detail the only thing that consumers should or should have the right to make decisions about when they're deciding whether or not to buy products. This is particularly true in a world where in some cases products are largely just functionally in terms of technical details relatively the same. The difference between a Nivea shampoo and an Olay shampoo is pretty much the same. It is up to consumers to decide whether they want to value things like the company's values or policy when they're making this decision. What does, in fact, advertisements that extend beyond things like, beyond technical details look like? Yes, it does look like flashy packaging and celebrities, but it also looks like companies promoting positive values, companies promoting their own charity work. All of these are things that companies do as marketing techniques to promote their brand. We think consumers have the right to know about these and consider them when they're making decisions. With that, let's introduce some responses to the material that they brought in. They basically had two ideas. First, on reinforcing negative stereotypes, and second, on creating better choices about which products to buy

and improving the quality of these products overall. On this first idea about perpetuating stereotypes, we have four responses. First, the fact of the matter is that these insecurities already exist, and to the extent that companies are preying on them. It's not like we're making them more increased on our side of the house, they're just, they already exist. But second, we actually tell you that company messaging is more likely to be positive than exclusionary and negative. At the point where companies have every incentive to promote as many people as possible to buy their product, it's more likely to be inclusive and positive. And third, to the extent that shaming messages were a marketing strategy in the past, we think that society is generally, in the large part, moving away from that. There is huge backlash to discriminatory policies. For example, when Dell came out with a line of laptops exclusively for women, that was pretty problematic. Or when companies engage in body shaming in the status quo to promote their products, there's massive backlash to that. And we see more and more companies like Fenty by Rihanna promoting inclusivity and body positivity instead of shaming women. But fourth and finally, we tell you that actually allowing companies to use things other than the technical details of their product to promote their product actually leads to a check back against those sorts of policies. They talked about the example of De Beers. What we tell you is that when other companies were able to talk about things like the way that they made their product more humanely than De Beers when they were doing advertising, which notably does not include the technical details of that product. They were able to call out De Beers for their massive human rights abuses, and this was something that we think consumers have the right to consider when they're making decisions. But on their other argument about increasing consumerism and leading to better products. First, this argument assumes that all products are super different. We don't think this is true, and we think particularly in these cases, people need to be able to choose other factors. Second, we think disparities in competition with advertising still exist at the point where the biggest companies are still going to be able to put out the most volume of advertising. These disparities are still going to exist. We actually think it's better on our side of the house when small companies are able to differentiate themselves by talking about the fact that they are in fact a

small brand rather than just focusing on product details. With that, let's introduce our first argument about how we better decision making for consumers and companies. First, let's talk about consumers. We tell you that what they say is spin actually helps consumers make decisions about what products to use. What does advertising do? It basically packages positive things about the product in easily digestible, appealing ways to attract people to that product. It's not just raw product details which can be really dry and boring for people to sift through. By using this packaging, people are able to learn more about the product and decide better for them. But also it means that consumers buy things that they otherwise wouldn't

because it is so dry and technical. For example, in many financial planning advertisements, there's illustrations of people like pulling a line of string to see how far their current financial reserves will get them in the future. This isn't about product details, but it illustrates that a lot of people have not enough money to get them through retirement. We think that this illustration, these positive illustrations, allow people to, say, buy financial planning services when they otherwise would actually bettering consumer decision making. But on to our second argument in today's round about how we encourage companies to engage in positive social policies. Three ideas under this, but before I introduce them, go. You may get corporate responsibility in some cases, but how does that interact with the other cases where Asian women are told they have to make their faces
whiter to look beautiful? We actually think the fact that companies promote this is something that consumers have the right to make decisions about. If a

consumer sees companies promoting these toxic mentalities, they have the right to choose to move to another company that doesn't engage in those practices. And we actually see a lot of societal backlash against things like that in the status quo. This sparks conversations about existing perpetuations of insecurities. We think this is very positive. But now onto how companies promote social movements. Three ideas under this. The first is by promoting social activism and charity. Two, boost PR. Companies engage in things like social outreach. This is the Delta example we've talked about. This is Ann Taylor running leadership programs for young girls. They do this to promote their brand, and in a world where they can't use this to market themselves, then the incentive to pursue those programs goes away. But second, it leads to better company policy. The ability to advertise about the practices that your company engages in creates an incentive to better those policies. This is companies like Audi implementing gender equality policies, or fair trade companies talking about how they use more positive labor practices in the global south to produce their product. The fact that companies are able to use these sorts of things to promote their product, which note, are entirely separate from the technical details, incentivizes better labor practices. Third and finally, we get actually more positive social messaging. Why are we more likely to promote positive values than negative values, as they say on your side of the house? We think that more positive values are far more inclusive and more likely to draw more people to your product. Companies have every incentive to do this. This is things like the Dove Like a Girl campaign, which empowers women. The Helpful Honda dealer ads, which promote values of helpfulness in society. And the Coca-Cola Pour the World a Coke campaign, which talks about increasing racial integration and decreasing discrimination. We think all of these would go away on their side of the house. But finally, we think that consumers fundamentally have the right to consider all of these things. And if there is in fact a negative value being perpetuated, that leads to discourse. And it's a legitimate choice for consumers to be able to make not to purchase that product. To boycott that product. Consumers have the right to decide if I want to buy the same shampoo, roughly the same shampoo, from a company that promotes the rights of women in the Global South versus one that does not.
and I would like to invite the second speaker of the opposition for their speech and would like to invite the reason why I should aspire to be a doctor should
never be because I want to buy a certain watch, or live in a certain home, or drive a certain car.

We think the aspirations of individuals for far too long have been focused on the materialistic ends that they can buy or purchase at the end of their career with. We think that was abhorrent. Because we think the only way to truly live a dignified life was to be able to have individuals focusing on the things that they can access. The way in which they live their lives, the jobs they have, and the hobbies that they adore, rather than the materials that they may or may not be able to buy. Because of that, I'm going to address this debate in two questions. Firstly, on the consumers. Secondly, on social change. But before that, I want to point out two things that Leader of Opposition missed entirely. The first one was the second argument that our first speaker brought to you. The one on producers. That is to say, she explained to you why oftentimes larger companies have an entrenched power when it comes to the competition of advertising. That they're uniquely able to do things like running campaigns off of the backs of expensive celebrities. That means that oftentimes it means that they're able to crowd out other companies at the expense of functionality. That is to say, they disincentivize competition to focus on the functionalities of items, but rather their ability to advertise them. And this then became problematic because it meant that their site neglected the actor that Stone tells you about. The actor that can benefit off of the increased functionality that is the result of competition. Individuals of lower socioeconomic status that are now able to purchase functional items because those are the result of competition. That prices of good items can now go down because companies focus on the functionality of items rather than their ability to advertise them. The second thing that they completely ignore is our worldview that we present to you. One that is much more positive. That is to say, one that rather than focusing on the ends that you try to buy, but rather the means by which you try to get those ends. The lives that you live trying to accumulate the materialistic things that their side wants to focus on. So I'm going to talk firstly about the consumers, the bulk of the analysis they brought to us, and secondly I'm going to give you a unique substantive that addresses the end of their leader of opposition speech, which is social change. We told you three things when it came to consumers. The first thing we explained to you was that they are oftentimes resulted to uninformed consent. That is to say the manufactured consent created by the advertisement is oftentimes manipulative and takes advantage of the vulnerabilities that these individuals have. Because of this, we told you importantly, when it came to sacrificing the money that these individuals earn

from a living wage, it became important to protect their ability to actually buy the products that benefited them rather than the ones that had the money to advertise themselves properly. The only response we heard here was at the end of the opposition, where they tell us that individuals should have a right to purchase these items. I have three responses. Firstly, the reason why this is not a right is because the necessity to buy these items is oftentimes created by these advertisements in the first place. That is to say, there is an incentive upon their side to create insecurities and create dissatisfaction with yourself, because that is the motivating force that is most likely to drive individuals to buy your product. That is why, on their side, you cannot consider it a right, because the necessity to buy these products never existed without the advertisements in the first place.

Why? Secondly, we tell you that this is also, we tell you that even if this right were to exist to some extent, you necessarily need it to balance out. And the problem with consumerism that Stone highlights that they completely ignore is the fact that it is necessarily exclusive. That is to say, the value of a Yeezy is only valuable to the extent at which not everyone can access it. Because of that, consumerism has an incentive to make the products that they try to sell inclusive to those who can afford it. This then becomes problematic. Because if individuals have a right to purchase these items, they probably shouldn't be coerced into buying the products that they cannot afford, spending their living wage on items that are not actually beneficial for them, but only ones that have been inflated by the advertisements that prioritize them. But thirdly, we would say if there was some sort of right for individuals to purchase the right product, we would much rather have a comparative, where they choose these items based off of functionality rather than the ones off of the advertising that they tell us about. The second thing that someone told you about was the perverse incentives of advertisement. That is to say, things like objectifying women in car advertisements, or things like how models are oftentimes the only way to properly dress clothes and because of it you create insecurities within individuals. The response here was firstly that this was justified because you were highlighting technical goods that were otherwise too dry. We think the unfortunate reality of this is that that's on our side. That on our side we do be able to highlight the best things and products because that's still focusing on the technical details. So to that extent we probably consume that part of their case. But the second thing they told us is often times you need these advertisements to illustrate things beyond the technical aspects of the property you are. The things like the values that your company may want to convey. And we think this is the point at which they concede to our case, right? Because they concede the fact that companies can oftentimes mischaracterize the products that they are selling. Now, the positive matter from opposition's side is solely reliant on this one assertion. The assertion that every single message that is going to be passed is one that is good. Why is that unlikely and why is that even if it is true, it is still a bad thing? The first thing to note here is that this is uniquely unlikely. Why? Because the best ways companies know to actually sell their product is to make sure that everybody wants it. And the way in which you can do that is to create dissatisfaction within the customers. That is why we told you they oftentimes have an incentive to drive in the insecurities of individuals. But secondly, note the fact that even if it was true that some companies are promoting some good values, that these are always delayed in retrospective. That is to say, advertisement doesn't uniquely push forward the brunt of social change. And the reason why that is so is because advertisements want to appeal to the most people possible. That means even in their best case scenario, we're sure sometimes companies like Dove can tell you why their products cannot be uniquely masculine, that only happens after society already accepts things like that because that is the only way at which this type of marketing is ever able to actually reach a target audience. The third thing to note here is when they tell you that there's an incentive to be inclusive because there's often times backlash. But note the thing about the problem with this argument. It's because it conceives the fact that there is a problem and that backlash is the way in which they try to solve it. And note that in this debate, it's not a net positive for you to try to heal the problems that advertisement has already created. It is a net benefit on our side when we tell you that we eliminate the problem as a whole and we can still give you more benefits because we change the way people perceive themselves away from the materialistic world that they tell you. Lastly, I just want to address the examples of things like how Delta promotes their charity. Firstly, if Delta promoting their charity is actually as mischaracterizing as you tell us, we're happy to ban it as well on our side. But the second thing to note is if Delta, if buying Delta tickets has also a functionality of giving people charity, we think that's just a technical aspect of purchasing Delta tickets because the money that you put in also goes to charity. So if they want to advertise that that it's perfectly justified because it's another aspect of the product that they're trying to sell. Lastly then let's talk about social change. We think the problem within society is oftentimes important social messages are contradicted or crowded out by advertisements. That is to say it becomes extremely difficult to empathize with issues like race inclusion when the only thing that you see in advertisements are rich white people because that's the target audience that advertising companies want to hit. Importantly, this then means that corporations oftentimes have a superior incentive to sell their product rather than promoting the correct messages. So even if on their side they can name a few examples of good promotions, we think importantly what the problem is then is that the bad messages can oftentimes contradict the important social messages and then on our side we're able to clear out this headspace. We think importantly what the problem is then is that the bad messages can often have contradicted Important social messages and then on our side were able to clear out this headspace We're able to allow individuals to properly engage with the social messages that opposition side actually approves of because we think Advertisement is oftentimes quite delayed when it comes to social messages and it shouldn't be the way in which we try to change the public's appearance Instead we would rather take away the crowded information sphere that currently exists and allow for the important social messages to exist whilst products do what products need to do, which is focus on functionality so individuals can escape from the materialism that they want to talk about. Very proud to propose. All right. All right. I would like to thank the second speaker of the opposition for delivering their speech.

When we, as women of color, see a commercial for skin whitening products, we don't feel desperate in what to actually contribute and help to benefit our money to that company Rather we feel angry and want the ability to know that that actual product exists to know that that company supports something That we are opposed to and we think we are happy to be able to support things like Rihanna's makeup campaign for women of color to have more diversity in the makeup aisle as Consumers we have the right to this kind of information. That information does not simply disappear, that discrimination does not go away on their side of the house. The only thing that does is an individual's ability to know it exists. Very proud to oppose. In this speech I'm going to be doing a couple of things. First I'm going to be engaging with all the material you've heard so far coming out of the proposition before then delivering our

third substantive argument about the destruction of certain businesses, namely advertising and small businesses. But now, let's get into what we heard coming out of the proposition side of the house. In response to their model, remember, we think it's pretty unclear as to what exactly it is they're defending. We ask a very simple POI. Would you allow commercials such as Delta to advertise the fact that they have campaigns in sub-Saharan Africa and support those communities. They said yes because it's somehow distinct. We don't think it is, insofar as they tell you the reason that these commercials happen is to make a profit. Even if Delta's incentive to advertise is to gain support, we would argue that's a good thing because it means these programs are more likely to happen, leading to more positive social change. But now, let's get into addressing the two

key questions in the debate. The first argument that we hear in the point of clash is about this idea of whether or not advertisements have positive or negative messaging. We're going to analyze why we win on both fronts. They talk to us about this idea that we intensify stereotypes and they tell us that advertisements pander to existing stereotypes and thus will be discriminatory towards women and minorities. We have a responses first off in challenge of the current trend of advertising is simply reinforcing negative stereotypes companies have structural incentives to cater to as many people as possible and a moment of embracing positive social movements for example black is beautiful or more diversity or more women in the actual positions of power we think that is why empirically it is true look to the example of Dove's Like a Girl campaign, Audi's Equal Pay commercial, where Yarnas make a brand to service women of color. But now, let's engage them on their highest ground, because we think we want to be as direct as possible. If a company airs advertisements that perpetuate stereotypes, we think actually it can be a good thing for consumers to know those companies have biases. Why is this the case?

First off, consumers have a right to know those companies have biases. Why is this the case? First off, consumers have a right to know if their company is discriminatory. If I know that Avino uses the slogan that white is purity, I have a right to know to boycott them. But secondly, we do think that creates an effective check on these negative messaging through backlash. We gave you two examples of this happening. The first is whenever Dell launched a laptop that was specifically made for women. Within that exact same month, the entirety of the laptop and the website correlated it was discontinued because of backlash. The second example is the Kendall Jenner Pepsi commercial that we tell you led to a lot of backlash and more discourse in society, both of which means the companies are harmed, not supported. On the comparative, why is it so important for me to know what a company values? We think the standard that women, for example, should have lighter skin exists on both sides of the house, but it's only through marketing that we have a mechanism to expose and fight against that. But even so, let's talk about what commercials really look like. In the proposition world, we think it looks like simply having these kinds of technical information and not the message that is associated with it. Insofar as we tell you we are the only side that has a mechanism to do things like spreading these positive messaging, we think that at that point we win this argument on a pretty clear level.

But now let's get into the second argument that they had, which we thought was quite strange, on combating consumerism. A few responses. First off, they never explain how changing commercials means that what actual individuals want will change or how consumerism will go down. Rather, consumerism and wanting to be rich existed long before advertisements did. Perhaps materialism has harms, but they do not combat that or explain why this is the case. They tell us that individuals ought to solely choose based off of functionality. We think advertisements beyond technological goods do just that because we think that individuals have the ability to know more about the companies themselves. That was the analysis they did not engage with. But for example, what we would additionally say is we can actually help to have better consumer choices. Look to examples of insurance commercials that display a family in a car crash. Oftentimes, it is these advertisements that, yes, might not simply be about a lot of data or facts, but that help individuals to realize how necessary some goods are. We are the only side that can access that benefit. But now let's talk about the argument

about how competition is going to be harmed and how it's going to harm producers. We think our second argument, the second speaker claims that Ella didn't respond. She directly engaged this argument, even though they didn't get to it in Prop 1 until the seven minute mark. We told you that technological details exclusively being the focus of commercials enables things like monopolization. For example, if only Apple is the one to be able to actually market off of how good their technology is, that means they have intended to do things like aggressively increase patents and be able to actually take over larger shares of the market. At that point, competition only gets worse under their side of the house because of a lack of ability to distinguish themselves. The last argument is about this idea that we have corrects and false advertising. First off, we said regulations promote fact-checking. Second, we can still punish companies through lawsuits and actual heavy fines from the government. Third, we can see things like counter-advertising. For example, with our own De Beers example, we think that actually other diamond companies had counter-examples about how they had more humanitarian ways to extract resources. And fourth, on backlash of the public, deterring negative images. Before we get into the third argument, I'll take a point. Not everyone responds so positively to stereotyping advertisement. Why is it the responsibility of those who react to it negatively to bear the burden of exposing corporations on your side? We think that, for example, if I'm an individual of colour that sees an advertisement for skin whitening products, we think that first off, we can have large societal backlash to that,

meaning that we can have more information on our side of the house that supports getting rid of these negative stereotypes altogether like things like the like the girl campaign like things like Brianna's
makeup brand let's go into our third argument our first layer of analysis is

harms to the advertising industry we want to take a moment to consider the huge volume of individuals involved in creating advertisements themselves for example behavioral scientists copywriters data analysts that consult with different testing groups networking consultants executives that run the businesses themselves actors and actresses indie commercials video editors sound editors directors artists graphic designers there are so many examples of this happening we think just to be clear a lot of these skills aren't portable to other industries that's just 12 of the many positions that compose the advertising industry. Advertising is a multi-billion dollar industry, and their side of the house. In order to access any of their benefits about combating consumerism, this industry necessarily needs to narrow and necessarily needs to suffer. We think that's problematic because at best, some networking jobs remain, but since the focus of the product itself is the only thing that's considered, the rest disappear, harming millions of individuals in that industry itself and all of their families. Our second layer of analysis is about

limiting the content of ads that harm small businesses. This directly answers your argument about competition. And if Rofo were just focused on technical details, that just means large companies get informed to advance technology and seek out high advertising with even more of an advantage. Small businesses benefit from being able to engage in things like creative marketing or even marketing based on the fact that they are, yes, a small business. The proposition removes this mechanism for small businesses to distinguish themselves as a brand because now they only have to focus on the product itself. At the end of the day, on every point of classes come with the debate so far,

we think it is too late for the proposition we are so proud to oppose. Thank you. justified, extending on what Brian said in his speech. Because we think it's very clear. We would say then that that's incredibly problematic because advertising is pervasive, you can't avoid it. So in justification of market outcomes as to why we ban fraudulent advertisement, in justification of why we value the ability of individuals to select their own identity and form that, which is, I would note, the premise of democracy, because other people can't tell you what you should value, we would say then that we should ban these things.

I'm going to ask two questions in this speech. Firstly, how do we promote better social values? Secondly, how do we get better market outcomes? Let's talk about social values. This creates a necessity to advertise in this way as well. That is to say that when you buy this car, you are part of an elite group, that you are better than other individuals, and therefore you buy into this idea of exclusivity. But secondly, that their net impact is very small. That these are things that we can and should be regulating. And note, also, that ads follow change. They do not create change. Yes? Okay, we tell, we, I would want to know why would I want a majority male government to regulate what products can be sold to women?
I think that generally governments aren't as evil as you say they are, but even if that's the case, right?

you should ban the hate speech because it's hurting people right now. Ultimately consumer choice should be in the way of mechanism in this debate. I'm incredibly proud to propose. All right. Thank you. In this speech, I'll be doing a few things. I'll be discussing two key questions that should summarize today's debate. The first, on which side does what's best for consumers? We think that in and so far that we live in an industry where there's multiple companies selling the same products, a lot of products choose to be relatively similar, meaning that if there's only telling you the technical product details, it's all going to look the same. That's why advertising is used in the first place, because they're trying to get a company to be able to succeed, to give unique things about their products that makes it a reason to buy into those products in the first place. Why is this the case? Because they recognize that just only having products that include technical details is the only way to sell your products, well then I'm going to want to have the most technical details to be able to sell my product in the first place. When you only can talk about product details, you shut out small businesses from their key selling point. destroy that market we stand firm on opposition All right. Thank you. and I would like to invite Ella to deliver a last speech of the American people.

The idea that light skin is somehow superior to dark skin is an idea as archaic, old, and toxic as literally the Indian caste system. Products designed to address this arose in response to existing problematic biases and ideas in society. On our side of the house, when we allow both companies to draw attention to these problems through marketing campaigns, but also other companies to check back against these very problems. We think that is the way that we actually solve such toxic social issues in society. We're very proud to oppose.

Two questions in the speech. First, which side creates the best social impact? And second, which side creates the best economic impact? Let's start with the social impact. First, as we tell you, we established that all of the insecurities and problems that they talk about on their side of the house, as we tell you down we established that all of the insecurities and problems that they talk about on their side of the house, as we tell you down the bench, are created by advertisers, but are just capitalized on by advertisers. What if we tell you down the bench, when we actually draw attention to these problems, and allow consumers to make decisions about whether they want to buy into and support such toxic ideologies, we actually create more discourse discourse and can check back against these narratives. We tell you that because most companies are not selling exclusive luxury products and in fact do want to cater to a large majority of people, they are much more likely, particularly as society progresses, to cater to more individuals and beat back against such toxic policies. But at worst, grant them that we marginally increase existing toxic ideas and insecurities.

On their side of the house, they are never going to get the benefits that we tell you about in our second argument about promoting social movements and charitable efforts by companies. What did they tell you in response to this? Their responses were both inadequate and in some cases a little bit offensive. They told us that governments should just engage in forcing companies to pursue these policies. Governments that are so coerced by problematic advertising, apparently on their side of the house, we don't think this is likely. But also, we don't think governments can force companies to engage in positive messaging or charitable work. That is only something that comes about when you give them a profit incentive for them to be able to promote these kinds of efforts to be able to sell products. When you allow companies like Delta to promote the fact that they're engaging in charity work that helps thousands of people in sub-Saharan Africa, or a company like Ann Taylor to promote the fact that they're creating leadership programs for girls. But another argument that they came up in response to this was that, well, these advertising campaigns only come up when this movement has already begun, so they make absolutely no difference because the problem has already been solved. I am sorry.

Does the pay gap not exist between women and men? Do ideas of toxic masculinity and discrimination not exist? We think that advertising campaigns to overthrow such toxic ideas may follow existing movements to do so, but uniquely promote these ideas. And we think that is incredibly important. But they say that they outweigh this because it's super coercive for me to buy an iPhone because I like the packaging. Well, I was going to buy a phone anyways. We don't think that it is ridiculously coercive, just even if we accept that people are just buying it because they're packaging to do so. But we also tell you that individuals should factor in other things other than the technical product value. They should factor in things like the company's ideology and that they have the right to do so. So on this question alone, we take the debate. But now let's move on into the second question in this round about the economic impact. Their link here is basically that people make more objective decisions because suddenly, because advertising doesn't exist, I don't want a Rolls Royce more than I want a Honda. We think that that dynamic existed on both sides of the house, and people have always wanted to buy better products and things like that. And as Layla tells you, they're not so irrational that they're going to destroy their financial futures in the name of consumerism. But we also told you about the value of appealing to simple, appealing messaging to explain to people what the benefits of a product are, particularly for really technical products that people otherwise wouldn't buy for financial gain. But we also told you about the impact on small businesses and the massive impact on the advertising industry. We think on the economic point, we also take today's debate. The marginal harm that they get on their side of the house do not outweigh the massive societal benefits and economic benefits we get on our side of the house.

I'm going to be quite frank. I wish I lived in the very narrow conceptualization of the world that we get from Team USA. That when I saw an Old Spice commercial or a Hollister commercial and I saw the person with ripped six-pack abs, I wouldn't feel bad about my own body. But unfortunately, that was not the reality of the world

that we lived in. Not every individual lived in a liberal country and decided to become an activist the second they were able to identify the implicit messages that corporations stuffed into their advertisement. What was a lot more realistic was a world in which people, especially the ones who already live in conservative circles, saw the advertisements that exploited their insecurities, exactly as Prabhupada told us.

That when they capitalized upon these insecurities, it made it a lot worse, because they displayed them all across any facet of their lives. It meant that every single aspect of their person, everything that they purchased, was only done because of the insecurities that they saw. Because ultimately, all of the benefits of social change and backlash and exposing corporations only happened on their side. If individuals who were looking at these ads were so attentive enough that they were able to perceive the implicit messages that somehow they were able to get past, that they were the ones that were willing to act against it because they themselves were not insecure. Unfortunately, those confident activists may be Team USA, but they are not the vast majority of the world, and that is why it became problematic.

That social change should probably be left up to the people who had the burden to carry it, not the individuals who had their lives demeaned because the advertisements told them that the life they live is not the satisfactory one to live. We told you social change should be left up to the political and social activists that are able to, once you were able, to clear out the space that advertisements currently held.
So then, I'm going to explain to you then in three areas why we want this debate, even on the consumerism side, even if we have lost the social change side.

Firstly then, when it came to the quality of the products and this is probably where they engaged upon us with the lease because we told you that when functionality is the metric by which corporations have competition it means that they improve their functionality that they lower the cost and importantly individuals and lower socioeconomic statuses could access the benefits of capitalism that it always had promised them, but unfortunately were distracted because advertisement was a game that companies had to win. Importantly, this was a group of individuals that could now afford things like maybe a jacket on a cold winter night. A group of individuals that opposition neglected, but we repeated to you through all of our speeches.

Secondly, when it comes to the matter of choice, ultimately the opposition's reply to our argument about choice was that they told us there is a right to be materialistic. But the problem all along the bench that we characterized to you was that it is not a right if you do not have a choice. At the point of which, yes, maybe Ella wants to buy an iPhone, but every other individual in the society that cannot afford this iPhone now necessarily feels excluded because consumerism idealized the idea that you were the only one that was able to gain access to these attributes that define your core identity. Ultimately, we told you, a right cannot exist if it excludes the vast majority of the population. Yes, on their side, a rich man can feel benefited because they purchased the justifiable product. But on our side, we told you that everyone should have been justified because they should never have been coerced into buying the most expensive item but the one that they needed most.

Lastly then, on insecurities. The only solvency they had on their side to solve the problem of insecurities within advertisement was backlash. But that fell problematically on two assumptions that they made. The first one was that individuals could identify the implicit messages that oftentimes companies were hiding because they wanted to influence you without you realizing. We told you that was probably unrealistic. People don't see the fact that this company is trying to create negative stereotyping. What they see is the fact that this person has a much nicer body than the one that they possess, that they're dissatisfied because they aren't able to have that exact same lifestyle. Then, importantly, it means that even in their best case scenario, if we took them at the top of their case, some people, yes, might realize that advertisements are terrible, but most people will never realize that, and their lives will permanently be demeaned because those advertisements always seek to tell them that your life is not the life you should be living. Very proud to propose.

title: WSDC 2018 QF: England VS USA
description:
Quarter-finals (impromptu):

This House believes that foreigners should not be allowed to own land in developing countries.

Team England won against Team USA on a 5:2 split.
motion: This house would ban foreign ownership of land in developing countries.

argument_units.text: I would now like to invite a speaker for sidewalks. Rana Plaza was a factory owned and operated by the Western clothing manufacturer Primark in Bangladesh, which because of lax standards which had been able to bully out of local governments collapsed killing hundreds of workers. But Primark's power did not go away and because of the economic stranglehold which foreign landowners have over developing world countries, Primark still owns and operates upwards of 25 similar factories.

Look, right now huge swathes of the developing world are on the brink of being able to develop local infrastructure and industries in a way which is sustainable for the future and profitable for those countries. But local investors are being crowded out by giant foreign multinational corporations and individuals who don't care about the people or the future of those economies, but who rather only care about taking every last drop of oil out of that country, every last drop ounce of gold, leaving the countries destitute and unable to pull themselves out of poverty. On Team England, we say you can't pull yourself out of poverty if you have nothing to grab onto, and foreign ownership of land yanks away the bottom rung of that ladder preventing development. With that in mind, we're bringing you three points. One, why foreign investment harms these countries. Two, how we get better development in the form of local enterprise. And three, how we increase the accountability of businesses in the developing world.

What's our stance in this debate? Two things. One, we oppose foreign individuals or foreign-based, not locally registered companies from owning or renting land as a form of 21st century colonialism. We say foreign individuals and fat cats buy up vast swathes of land and national resources like oil fields or rainforests and then charge local businesses to use them or force local people to work for them for pennies. Two, what is our role for development on the clock? We think the local people are more than capable of developing this land and if

they did, it would be better in the long run. My first point is about why foreign ownership is bad by comparison to locals. First, because there is a race to the bottom among foreign owners. Because the incentives of people who run these large corporations and foreign companies is to threaten companies themselves to do things like lower regulations, that's in terms of workers' rights, and in terms of environmental rights, to do things like lower taxation, to do things like often literally give them subsidies. The reason they're able to do this in a way that locally registered companies aren't is because these companies can threaten to move abroad to set up industries, to set up businesses and buy land in other countries if the governments don't concede to their demands. Secondly, because foreign owners are more likely and

more able to exploit the countries that they're in. That's because these companies, these individuals, have no long-term stake in the countries that they're investing in. They have no incentive to, for example, preserve the existence of natural resources. We tell your population that natural resources are some of the key assets that these countries have. So on the comparative, we would actually prefer a slower development in a way which is sustainable, and which people who are local actually benefit from.

So when BHP Billiton builds a mine in Cajamarca in Argentina, they used cyanide in order to extract the gold from the rocks. The reason they did that was because it was enormously cheaper in the short term. But that cyanide leaked into local river sources which meant the nearby town of 300,000 people was no longer able to access clean, safe, drinkable water. That's exactly the kind of thing that foreign companies do, at the point where they're able to bully governments into letting them do it in the first place, and don't care about the locals in that community. Thirdly, foreign companies develop land in ways that are against the incentives of locals.

One, because they tend to import workforce, especially they import for managerial positions, workforces from their local companies. That means they have no incentive to invest in infrastructure and education for local individuals. In the most extreme cases, this looks like Chinese companies shipping in workers en masse to build railways, to build roads, not employing locals, even a little bit. Thirdly, they take money out of the economy, because the money that these companies that invest in land make gets removed from the economy, goes back to their own companies, goes back to their own countries. Finally, because they develop resources in turn to their own interests and not what's in the national interest, i.e. they might build a railway or a road, but that railway or road is going directly from the mine which they own to the port which they own and doesn't actually help local individuals.

So let's ask the question, why, if it's so bad for these countries to have these big investors and foreign investors, why do they let them do it in the first place? Three reasons. One, because there is an international consensus around the necessity of multinational companies propagated by the neoliberal global agenda. This is something which we think is just a luck, and nascent economies tend to buy into this because they've seen it work in a few isolated instances that actually is not beneficial for them in the long run. We prefer a lot of countries like China, who by protecting local industries, by protecting local resources, have been able to develop long-term industries that actually have benefited more. Two, because these companies operate in a self-competiting cycle. Because once a few big multinational companies have been let into your economy, have started buying land, they drive up land prices in a way which prices out local competitors. So you have no choice as a company but to accept more land. Finally, because these countries are competing with other developing nations, because if a neighbouring country uses a multinational corporation to develop, they might develop faster but less sustainably. The problem is, it lowers the work of the things that you're developing. So as soon as one country in a region, for example, which is developing, uses multinational corporations, uses foreign investment, that makes it enormously easier for them to live in the short term, which forces other companies to also do that, lest they be priced out, lest they be shut out of those markets, particularly in things like oil, for example, where other companies, like multinational corporations, are able to lower prices in the short term, which means that the countries have no other choice but to turn to these kind of corporations.

Before I talk to you about how we encourage local industries and why that's so good, I'll take a point of information. Would your side of the house not allow an immigrant from South Sudan to own land in Sudan? So, first, we think that there are lots of processes by which individuals who immigrate into a country, if they are genuinely invested in that country, can become citizens. We're quite happy for those individuals to exist in those countries and to function as part of the economy of those countries. title: Macau Online WSDC 2021 Octo Finals 4 (Hong Kong vs Australia)
description:
Motion: This House would ban users from selling their data to companies in exchange for financial returns (i.e. receiving fixed monthly rates, dividends, etc., for the use of their data by companies)
Proposition: Hong Kong
Opposition: Australia

Prop wins
motion: This House Would Ban Companies From Paying Users for Their Data.

argument_units.text: We all fall victim to companies like Robinhood paying you $1 a month when it only leads to the exploitative use of data, when individuals can never know where their data ends up and what it is used for, when it actively undermines the hard and long thought journey we have embarked to ensure individuals engage in online activities safely.

The critical issue we have to answer in this debate is which side protects the user's privacy and choice that is prone to infringement and exploitation. Our response is that users selling their data is a euphemism for the exploitation and extreme infringement of privacy that is inherent to allowing companies to pay you to access your data. And Team Hong Kong absolutely

will not condone this. Four arguments we will run. In my speech, one, why this choice is actively exploitative. Two, why it actively undermines privacy. Three, why it actively is unjust because it causes negative externalities. And fourthly, in Jenna's speech, why do you cause a monopolization of the tech industry? Before that, our model. We are fine

with the status quo, i.e. when Facebook does have access to parts of your data. In the status quo, there are obviously loads of regulations about what data companies can have access to. However, it is crucial to recognize there is a difference between selling your data and the status quo we are proposing on our side. What are the differences? We think when you sell your data, here are what things companies can exclusively do. They can sell your data to third parties. They can get more specific data, i.e. your medical data, your relationship, socioeconomic status, data from other platforms, biometric data, i.e. Apple can sell the photo you use for your face on their firms.

Virtually anything you can think of. Generally, these are more specific and personal data, and the more specific and personal it is, the more beneficial it is for companies. No, thank you. First argument, why is this choice exploitative? Our premise is that a coercive choice may not be bad, but a coercive choice that is exploitative is bad. If I force you to take $50, it's coercive, but no one will think that is bad. If I'm forcing you to give me 50 bucks, that becomes actively harmful and exploitative. Being able to sell your data for a small return per month pushes people to make bad choices when they are unable to make informed and good decisions. We protect individuals when the choice is actively harmful and exploitative. So the question becomes, why is this choice to sell your data exploitative? This is true for about three reasons. One, because of information asymmetry. The average person probably does not know too much about the tech sphere or what happens to digital data. It is unclear where your data goes, who receives it, when your data is monetized, or when your data is sold to third parties and companies. Once you sell your data, you have lost complete ownership of it. This is irreversible, and you do not know the parameters in which your data will operate in. You no longer can control where it goes because

companies are able to sell it to third parties however they like. But B, because in general, no one really reads the 19-page long terms and conditions written in microscopic fonts to check all the rules of the information in which they're shared. We already see this in the status quo, but we think it's far more coercive and harmful when you are not able to monetize your data. But C, we think in many cases, people have a short-term gain versus indefinite long-term harm belief. I.e., if I sell my data now, I don't really know where my data goes or what happens. It seems to me the harm is not very obvious, but I do know each year I can earn about 20 bucks. That seems like a decently attractive deal to make, and most people will definitely opt into this. We think that is actively harmful. But what is even more harmful is that there's a collective action problem,

where if only you yourself are selling your individual data, that probably isn't too big of a problem. It only becomes a problem when everyone else is doing it as well, because that is when data and big data becomes useful. This means that you actively leave people behind. When you force all individuals to tend to give up data because of the network. Because for opposition to have any tangible impact, they need to have the vast majority of people selling their data in order to make big data and proper analytics. This normalizes data selling on their side. It becomes more likely that many services will be contingent upon giving up privacy, not just from social media companies like Facebook and Spotify, but potentially crucial financial services, i.e. having a reasonable interest rate bank account or access to retirement saving advertising. These are actively harmful. This means that the most vulnerable people, those who probably do not want to sell their data, some people who have a past they would like to forget about, people who they no longer want to associate with their lives. These are not the people who are shut out from essential services entirely, or they're more pressured to surrender the privacy they hold, as these are the individuals that will fall victim to the system. Therefore, you actively undermine choice for other people. Why is this so harmful? One, because companies

are able to sell it to third parties, i.e. you are able to sell data to companies that do facial recognition. That can actually be sold to the police, the state, and many surveillance agencies. Why is this so dangerous? In the worst of states, you can use it for surveillance and active oppression, i.e. many Chinese companies are already selling data to government surveillance agencies to monitor minority groups. But even in countries that aren't fully authoritarian, states could still use it in select situations to arrest and identify protesters. We think, in general, the harm is too great to be absorbed.

But compared to the status quo, why are we better on our side? Because we think even if your data can be circulated, there are heavy regulations that protect it. And regulations are in fact already improving in many countries, as companies like Facebook are receiving higher standards of scrutiny. But on their side, once you sell your data, it is no longer yours. The parameters as to where your data circulates never becomes clear because it can be sold to any party on their side. You lose control over your data. Therefore, the conclusion of this argument is that exploitative choices are unjust and actively harms people when they're unable to make informed choices. Before I move on to my question, I'll take a POI. Do you support people getting paid for things like professional wrestling or boxing? If their concern is about bodily autonomy, we say on our side, your access to your rights actively infringes on other people's rights and causes massive harm. That is non-analogous. Second argument, why you undermine privacy and worsen regulation.

The premise of this argument is that privacy protects you. It is important because it is part of your identity. It is part of who you are and your fundamental right to yourself as to how much you want to expose. The mechanism is why does it mean that it's actually undermined on their side? Because what does the status quo look like? Often when you have regulations, you are absolutely prohibited to sell data to third parties. Even if Facebook can use your data for advertising, they're never able to sell it out of their current company. These are rules that you can set up. If companies violate them, you can punish them retrospectively and enforce deterrence. You can advocate for better regulation. This looks like a lot of class action lawsuits that already happened against Facebook. Advocacy is based on the fact that it is your data. It highlights the idea of consent. It is based on the idea that companies are massive and are exploiting you. The comparative on their side is that you now lose the ability to advocate when companies have bought the data, when regulations are already circumvented and broken. They have sacrificed huge amounts of money to create that business model of selling and using data. If you try to tell them that they need to change it, they're not able to act against you because you have already given up your consent and given up the idea of protection. The conclusion of this argument is that one, you have decreases in regulation. This looks like the regulation of not selling information to third parties, which is often massively harmful. But two, it is difficult to get future regulations, i.e. when you are able to sell things like biometric data, facial recognition, AI, for things like receipts, to calculate risk rates, and calculating who to give mortgages to. This means it's far more harmful if the harm is actively magnified when you sell and monetize your data. Quickly on the

third argument, why does selling your data lead to negative externalities of others? The premise of this argument is that your data is closely tied and connected to others. Selling your data means you're also selling other people's data without their consent. That is unjust and actively harmful. You have violated a choice that someone else rightly owns. Why is this true? Because your data is inherently linked to other people. If my location information is sold, it shows me at my partner's house. That tells you how much about them as it is to me. Structurally, because of how interdependent we are to each other and how we use technology in
all circumstances, such as in our relationships, in group meetings, with our family, our data must feature information about someone else. This is bad for a reason, because one, there is a

non-consensual choice. Those are the individuals who have their data sold without your consent. It undermines any monetary benefit that opposition wants to get at. The more people have already sold their data because of the networking effect, the less and less you will be paid, because companies essentially already have their data. There's a lesser demand for it. The conclusion is that we think data selling is not a matter of individual consent and autonomy. It is unjust because other people are equally harmed. Team Hong Kong refuses to allow exploitative companies to pray off individuals' identity.

Yeah we're all here. You're all in the same room right because one of the devices dropped off so I'm just checking right okay great thanks. So thank you very much for this proposition. If the judges are ready I'd like to call the next speaker. All right, great. Without further ado, I call the first opposition speaker to give the opposition case.

Hi, I'll be taking POIs in the chat, please. Assuming I'm audible, starting in three, two, one. Team proposition needed to get up here and tell you why they wanted to ban the selling of data collection, not just why it might be beneficial to regulate the data collection, because the reality is they had to set up infrastructure that would allow for banning, that we actually thought we could repurpose for some of the regulation that might be beneficial. But ultimately, they needed to justify a blanket ban on this policy, not simply like give you some minor harms that could eventuate. This was a strategic failing of them, and it's something I'm going to analyse deeper in my speech. Firstly, two questions to set up. What do these exchanges look like? We think these exchanges operate on a scale, from cash-in- hand transactions for surveys on the street to companies offering discounts on products in exchange for data collection that might look like lifting a paywall, for example. Secondly, on our stance, because for propositions policy to work, they need some means to regulate how companies collect that data. Clearly, their policy would be a failure if Google can keep flattening these guidelines and collecting data anyway for money.

Opposition: Malaysia
