title: Scotland vs USA   WSDC 2018   Round 5
description:
The decision in this debate was a 3-0 win for the USA. 

The motion: This House supports a school voucher system. 

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This house would implement a school voucher system.

argument_units.text: Now I invite the first speaker for side proposition. Thank you. There are children across the world who will never pose for a graduation photo, sit in a boardroom or have their voices heard in national parliament. Not because they lack effort, ambition or intellect, but because of the size of their parents' bank balance.

Team Scotland is proud today to support a system that will address educational disadvantage by giving poor pupils a ticket out of the tyranny of the birth law. We recognise that each country has a unique education structure in terms of finance and organisation but the broad features of the policy we support are characterised by the following three criteria.

Firstly, we define a school voucher as a sum of money equivalent to the average cost of educating a pupil in an administrative area which families can claim from the government to put towards funding a place as a private school. Secondly, we support a system where such vouchers are allocated on a means-tested basis, specifically to target low-income families, as seen in the example of Columbia. Thirdly, at the point at which private schools under our model are receiving public funds, we would expect a certain degree of state oversight in terms of them meeting basic standards

of teaching quality and curriculum provision. Notice two things about the context of this debate. Firstly, while this is one type of educational reform we support, we do not think it is mutually exclusive to us. We are happy to support other means, but we believe that this method is incredibly important in promoting quality education for all. Secondly, we would characterise this as a reallocation of existing public money rather than a reform that would require additional public money. We think therefore, in the absence of any additional funds, the very best world Team USA can realistically present to you today in this debate is the public education system under the status quo.

Noting that, Team Scotland worked into four lines of argumentation. Firstly, talking about the injustice of education, the quality of education under the status quo. Noting that point, teams fall into four lines of argumentation. Firstly, talking about the injustice of education, the quality of education under the status quo. Secondly, talking about how school vouchers empower individuals. Thirdly, how they elevate communities. And in my point of hand, it's going to be talking about how they bring improvements

to the school system in general. So now onto my main point of substance, the injustice of the status quo. The main contention that I'd like you to consider is that under the status quo, the school system serves, no thank you, as a tool to perpetuate and maintain social inequality. But before I begin, I want you all to imagine the daily life of a child attending a public school. It looks like the life of Daniel, a 14 year old boy from South Carolina who has to go through a metal detector before he goes to maths class, where it's likely that the teacher won't even show up. Recognise that there are only two ways that children like Daniel can hope to get a better education. Firstly, if their family has moved to an area served by a better public school. But this is based upon the assumption that they can afford to buy a hedge, I'll take you in a second, in an area where property prices are driven up by demand because of the school's reputation for being good. Before I go into the second method, a POI. Do you believe that the only way to be able to save students from this atrocious public school system is just to avoid and scrap the entire public school system in the first place? We don't think it's scrapping the public school system. My partner is going to be talking about how this move motion actively creates incentives for the public system to improve. What we're saying is that on an individual level, if we are ever to create social mobility and benefit these people's lives, they have to have a quality of education, they have to have equality of access. That is why we promote this motion. Secondly, the only other way that you can get a quality education program is if you abdicate in the land use from the public school system altogether and go to a private school. Again, assuming that you can afford the high tuition fees. Notice the sickening trend.
These are only viable options if you have the money. The status quo offers a quality education in the land use to those with a family built

upon the financial capacity capital to afford it. If families cannot afford these paths, Daniel and hundreds of thousands of other children across the world have trapped in a public school system which specialises in nothing but crushing their dreams on a daily basis.

Team Scotland needs justice is a gross and injustice for four reasons. Firstly, the quality of education that you receive is one of the most important tools that individuals can use to broaden your life chances and achieve success, whether that be through furthering your education or getting contacts to allow you to set up a business out of school. All of these opportunities that children attending poorer public schools are completely deprived of. Secondly, these children aren't deprived because of any personal failings. They have simply lost at a birth lottery. Realistically, we tell you that if these children, no thank you, had been born with exactly the same personal characteristics but a different set of social circumstances, they would have the opportunity to shine just as bright as any of those lucky enough to be born into a life of privilege. Thirdly, no thank you, we think this injustice is made even more insidious in the fact that the socio-economic inequality often overlaps with other dimensions of social inequality, for example race, because these minority groups have experienced both historic and systematic deprivation of financial capital to allow them to access a good education in the first place. Fourthly and finally, it is a self-perpetuating spiral where you miss out on a good education and you can't get a good job to raise yourself up and to promote yourself in society. What this does is it locks entire communities in a destructive cycle where there is a generational deprivation of hope for getting a good life.

What we tell you is that the school voucher system will correct these injustices. Moving on to my second substan-so which is talking about how we will cover individuals. The main intention of this being school vouchers allow individuals to unlock and exploit potential that was unacknowledged in the status quo. We believe that our model rectifies the injustice detailed in our first substan-so by giving low income families the tools to experience better quality education despite the limits of money. Specifically we tell you it targets students with a wealth of potential that is less than knowledge, that are allowed to go to schools with better teaching and better resources. We think this comes with two main objectives. Firstly, you don't have to live in a situation where you cannot access your own potential or even realise that you have potential in the first place. We think it's an incredibly frustrating life when you realise that no matter how hard you work and how much effort you put in, your future has already been determined by the circumstances of your birth. We think under this motion it changes when accessing cases and you allow people, no thank you, to define their own future rather than it being defined for them by society. Secondly, the second benefit is that you can better people's futures when you give them an opportunity to access jobs that were previously not for people who seemed to be, not for people like them. This is professions like lawyers, doctors, chemists, all of them living people, fulfilling careers and with that the attached financial security to ensure social mobility and allow you to improve yourself in that case. It may be more difficult, but we believe if we improve one individual's life under this motion, we can get education to change his life for the better. We guarantee opportunity by widening access to these people. They have the means to get a chance to discover and implement a circle that they never would have before. My third point is

talking about elevation of communities. The main contention of this being, communities are elevated and benefited by implementation of school vouchers. Talking about the idea of minority group elevation, because we want you to recall that educational segregation due to money leads to the ghettoisation of minority groups, as I've proved earlier. We get principally when you mix people in private schools you can eliminate the roots of low-level prejudice that are based upon misinformation because the point at which you have contact with these people on a day-to-day basis, you're in classes with them, you're friends with people of different walks of life, that is when the misinformation no longer has an effect on you. We think they're also represented practically at the point at which even if one person in the community gets to go to a high level job that previously wasn't for people like them. That is a role model, that is an aspiration, that is what lifts the community up. Look, what we tell you is that school vouchers give society this raw potential. We believe in potential, we believe in futures without limits, we believe in school vouchers. All we ask is that you speaker of the side propositions.

Thank you. We fundamentally reject side propositions characterization that public schools are failing institutions beyond salvation. We think to the extent that there are some public schools with problems, that there are some individuals being left behind, the solution is to actually fix and lift up those public schools, not to abandon them and say, let's move some individuals to a different system, leaving all of those who are left behind in these institutions behind. We're so proud

to oppose today's motion. Before I introduce rebuttal to side propositions of material and introduce our two first substantive arguments, I'd just like to clarify something in this round. Under our side of the House, we'd just like to clarify something in this round. Under our side of the house, we would use the money that would be allocated to vouchers to actually improve public schools. If there are indeed problems with them in the status quo, we think the solution is to directly address them, not to just move a few individuals out of them. We tell you that we would do things like implement programs to decrease class sizes, increase specialized advanced classes, increase the number of, say, specialized school school schools like madness programs for certain subjects, increase teacher training and educational research.

When cities like Cincinnati did all of these things, they went from in 2003 being one of the more struggling school districts in the state of Ohio to meeting and exceeding state standards. It is more than possible to improve public school systems and the plight of every student in them. We believe that the state's responsibility is to promote the education of all children, not just some who end up getting vouchers.

That's why we're very proud to oppose. With that, let's introduce responses to side propositions material. They claim to have two arguments in this round, but their first, about essentially reducing inequality, was basically about how we move poor individuals to private schools, They claim to have two arguments in this round, but their first, about essentially reducing inequality, was basically about how we move poor individuals to private schools, which is principally good, and then their second argument was about how this practically achieves their success. Note that this was essentially one argument about lifting certain individuals out of public schools. We have three responses. First, we think that this is a remarkably individualistic approach to solving inequality. They said that on their side of the house, if they help just one person, that's enough for them to succeed. But, we think that this should go beyond just helping one individual. What do we tell you? That education is a public good, not a commodity that should be subject to individual choice. Public goods, as they say on their side of the house, are things so essential they can't be left to market to selectively provide to people. These are things like water, national security, and things like this. Education is a fundamental part of this. Democracies rely on individuals to be informed so they can maximize the rights and resources that they use. And in its ideal form, anyone can take advantage of an education system to thrive in society. Which means, we think, what matters is that the public education system as a whole doesn't provide recipients exactly with what they want, but rather that the entire system of education can help as many people as possible. Just as under, say, a public transportation system, the government doesn't use funds to make sure that one individual can, say, buy a Rolls Royce, but in fact ensures the collective benefit of the whole. Additionally, we think because education is funded with taxpayer dollars, it should focus on benefiting the entire taxpaying collective, not just one individual. At the point where we leave public schools behind, this goal is undermined. Our second response is that we actually think that low-income individuals are shut out systematically on their side of the house. Even if they do restrict this to low-income individuals, we think it is going to be the privileged groups within those societies, say white low-income individuals, that are going to be able to take advantage of this. This is because hidden costs beyond the tuition that the voucher provides, things like transportation costs, are going to mean that the lowest- income individuals are shut out of the system. Selective admissions that private schools often use are going to mean only those who already have an educational advantage can even get in. But our final response to all of their recommendation is that they assume that these individuals

are better off in private schools. We think in many cases private schools are actually worse. We'll explain this more in our second substantive argument. With that, let's introduce our first argument about how this harms students who remain in state school systems. Practically, we think the state school system is the most important consideration in this round. Why? Just empirically, it has more students. It is basically impossible for a voucher system to move every single student out of, if you grant that, public schools are low-performing schools. In Chile, the most extensive voucher system in the world, only about half of students are able to take advantage of this. In the large majority of cases, more people are going to be in public schools. But second, as we tell you, those who remain in state schools are going to be the least advantaged in society. Who can't, you know, get into a selective school. Who can't cover those hidden costs. Who can't pay for the additional tuition on top of the voucher. This undermines education in three ways. First, it decreases resources and students for public schools. When students leave the public school system, they take the funding that was attached to them with them. Unfortunately, this means that even though schools have fewer resources, there are some costs that are the same no matter how many students you have. title: USA (prop) vs Scotland (opp) - WSDC 2019   Round One
description:
This House believes that governments should actively prevent gentrification.

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. 

The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This House believes that governments should actively prevent gentrification.

argument_units.text: California. When she successfully evicted from her house of 47 years, her first stop would likely be a relative's couch. After that, she doesn't know. She now has to wonder where she will live, work, and raise her family. And as a team comprised of members who see gentrification every day in our own cities, we're incredibly proud to propose the motion.

This House believes that governments should actively prevent gentrification. Two things to chat about in this speech. First, a few notes on framing before delivering our first two standard arguments. But first, framing. What does gentrification look like? We believe that gentrification is the rapid influx of a significant amount of affluent people and businesses into a neighborhood that has historically been low income. On proposition, we specifically oppose the pace of this migration. What then is our model? We are going to prevent gentrification, meaning that we support policies that address

the root cause so that it never exists. Two things that we likely support. First, we will end government policies that promote gentrification, so no building high-end housing to attract wealthy young people, and banning policies like eminent domain that remove long-term residents to make space for new residents. Second, we are going to freeze property taxes and place rent caps in gentrifying areas in the event that gentrification raises those prices radically. Lastly, what is our stance?

We do not oppose all economic investment in gentrifying communities. We support it whenever it is designed to benefit the existing residents rather than attract affluent people. For example, this looks like tax credits for existing businesses over new outside projects, improving basic utility and infrastructure over creating outside resources, improving basic utility and infrastructure, over creating luxury buildings, and requiring new businesses to employ existing residents in the event that they need.

That being said, let's move on to our first substantive argument about how gentrification creates economic harm. The thesis of this argument is that gentrification brings displacement, forcing the most vulnerable citizens out of their homes. This happens in two ways. First, through rising prices. The influx of new residents in an electrified area creates an increased demand for the existing supply of housing. Landlords want to capitalize on this increased demand, and so they raise rents. As rents go up, people who cannot afford them are driven out, replaced by wealthier individuals who are willing to pay the higher prices. For example, place bidding in Portugal is rapidly gentrifying. This happened after the government attracted foreign investors and converted historic neighborhoods into housing for young professionals. Over the past year alone, rents have risen by 23%. The second way that displacement occurs is through increasing the cost of living. As people move into a gentrified area, the cost of living increases because new businesses will cater to those customers who will pay the higher prices. Even if you have access to affordable housing, people will still be displaced because they no longer afford to live in their communities. All of this is empirically confirmed. Over a 22-year period in the U.S., displacement was two times higher in gentrifying areas than it was in non-gentrifying ones.

But why does gentrification matter? Why does displacement matter? Two broad reasons. First, displacement imposes severe costs on individuals. It's difficult to find a place to live because some individuals, if they already live in economic areas that aren't super-stimulated, don't have the money for things like a security deposit if they want to start renting a new place. Also, children of these families are under the image of having to go to new school districts that probably won't be able to service their needs. And you see things like maybe a lack of public transportation in a new area that these individuals live in. So whereas before, your walk to work may have been like five minutes, now you probably have to take a bus that is over an hour long. Displacement compounds all of the harms that economically disadvantaged people already must face, but our model uniquely addresses this. By ending active government support, we slow down the pace of migration, and it is this influx of economic supply crunch that increases rents and costs of living. Even if some people move in, without active government support, that migration is much smaller, so it does not carry the same parts. The second broad impact of displacement is that it undermines local businesses. Local businesses are only able to sustain themselves through a loyal consumer base, because they may not be able to do things like aggressively advertise. Displacement takes away this base, but this is so important because the big businesses that replace them are unable to help the community in the same way. Because local businesses reinvest in those communities. For example, the excess profits that come from my bodega go back into that neighborhood, but the excess profits from Starbucks simply make Howard Schultz richer. We ensure on our side that people both have access to homes and local businesses that are crucial for facilitating economic sustenance.

Our second substantive argument is on the government obligation to prevent gentrification. Before I get on to that, go ahead. Do property prices go down significantly in areas that are subject to routine small business? I don't think that property values go down significantly. Rather, they stay what they were at the start of gentrification.
And as time goes on and these neighbourhood neighborhoods get developed with this public housing, we believe that the property values will rise

but slowly. On your side of the house, gentrification happens at exponential rates where these individuals come into these areas and significantly bring up a crisis and cause displacement because no one can adjust to the long term to those issues. Our second substantive argument is on the government obligation to prevent gentrification. There are two sources of this obligation. The first is that individuals have a positive right to a home. The home is the basis of all other rights. Without a home, you don't have a place to provide shelter or the most basic sense of well-being. That is why the Universal Declaration of Human Rights says that housing is a human right. Note that this is not just a shelter over someone's head. The right to a home also extends to things like geographic stability. Why is this the case? Because people's development, identities, and self-actualization are tied to the culture, community, and location that they call home. Thus, the destruction of these ties through displacement creates deep material and psychological harm. The government has the obligation to protect people from the forced abandonment of their communities and culture. This is why individuals who are displaced can't simply pick up their truth. People's lives, experiences, and future plans shouldn't be disposable for affluent young questioners. The second source of this obligation is the idea that people have a negative right to property. People have a right to property free from the state's interference. That is because this is the sphere of citizen lives that gives them meaning and allows them to exercise freedom. If we prove that gentrification is the result of government action, then it's akin to a government-imposed violation of people's rights to property, i.e. a state-sponsored eviction.

How does gentrification inherently require ongoing government support to exist? Two ways. First, the private market only exists because of implicit government support. Investors don't want to invest in poor neighborhoods because they're worried that they can never get a return. So only government policies like quote-unquote economic development programs, like tax credits for new businesses over tax credits for the poor and elderly can give them that assurance. That means government action is necessary to create a white limit for gentrification to occur. The second way this happens is that governments directly kick out residents for gentrification. They resort to policies like eminent domain, which means seizing people's property, knocking down their homes, and building commercial real estate. For example, the Lagos government of Nigeria used eminent domain to displace 10,000 people from the neighborhood of Morocco for quote unquote civilized development. At the end of the day, this debate is extremely
clear. Gentrification harms the most vulnerable populations. Government intervention is more than necessary.

We also told you on this office that anti-genification is a way for people to be completely involved from the best of the generations such as more jobs, such as better public services, things that they need to get work, things that are better in their area.

This is crucially important and this is where we want to be. On the second slide, we have this denomination of evacuation like housing, or health care workers. where we want to be. On the second side of the flash, though, so how does gentrification affect relations between housing and cultural groups? So we got this idea from a TV essay about how gentrification is bringing up the cultural groups, the effect that housing has on gentrification, and they like this to prove their government is wrong.

Okay, so this little deal. The stronger the gentrification in a community, the less likely it is to be gentrified. Because a lot of these are probably going to keep friending people of their community, who want to keep that alive. And they can probably get gender-cultivation in areas where actually the community are very strong, as more flexibility, more influx of people who come and go to that community. But then, crucially, the whole idea of gentrifying areas and just preventing active mixing of them, increases the Samaritan-Greece discrimination, which TSA is looking to fight, by making them no-go zone, areas and just preventing ethnic mixism increases the Samaritan British discrimination which the U.S.A. is looking to fight by making them no-go zones, by increasing the perception to other people that they shouldn't go there. We think that's incredibly harmful. It accentuates

the problem that the U.S.A. is trying to solve. And then, personally on this point, we told you that where people were being out of cities, at least increased their income via neighbourhood areas. Things that have really powerful, important effects, like policy-making, directly harms low-income neighbourhoods. We also told you there was very little response to this. Because taking money out of the city hall for extension means the city cannot reinvest that money into the credit areas. They cannot link up low-income communities to other parts of the city. They cannot improve the service, they cannot include improved education, they cannot solve all the travel crisis, right? Because the money has now left. It's only really one site in this debate today which actually increases the amount of activity in identified areas. It's only really one site that actually helps women residents get work, have decent housing, have housing at all, really. And it's only really one site that's saving errors in truth in the long term, not just in the immediate term. That site is Team Scotland, that's why you must go to this. Thank you. Thank you.

Whoop-dee-doo, opposition bloc. Say whoop-dee-doo to the thousands of people in Barry Farms, Washington, DC, who weren't displaced because they followed our model. Say whoop-dee-doo to the thousands of people in Paris who had socially mixed affordable housing because they followed our model. Say whoop-dee-doo to the thousands of people in Paris who had socially mixed affordable housing because they followed our model. You might have forgotten after the 12 minutes of the opposition block because they framed this debate as, let's build roads where roads don't exist. No, we're talking about Harlem. Harlem has roads and banks. The question of this debate is whether or not hard loan means rich white people to buy out their churches. That's what this debate was about. Two questions.

What is propositions best material? Why is it insufficient? Why then, and the second question, is why then is displacement the thing to care about in this round? First question, what is propositions best material? Why is it insufficient? This is as charitable as possible, assuming displacement doesn't occur.

Firstly, they told you that decreased rents through anti-gentrification policies encourage landlords to sell, displacing people. We gave you two responses, neither of which went responded to. First, remember the comparative. On their side of the house, every landlord wants to sell their property because luxury real estate developers are offering to sell it for three times what they're currently making. At worst, some landlords on our side of the house no longer make the necessary profit. We think on the comparative we're better. Second, we told you the only reason you would need rent controls is when rents rise due to gentrification.

Second big idea they gave you is that, oh, well, people can live in affordable housing if your displacement won't occur. I mean, fine, you're not hopeless, but it still feeds the majority of harms in our case. First, we told you that cultural organizations are linked to the place that exists. For example, we gave you BOPAP in Cape Town, South Africa, meaning the political mobilization that instigates the consolidated, motivated political blocs that you need to see economic investment disappear on their side of the house. Secondly, it proves their burden that they pushed on us about the government obligation to actively prevent, because at the point in which you move people out of their home and just to a house, you violated a right. The government obviously has an obligation to prevent the violation of rights.

The last offense they gave you is now big box stores move in, and that is good. We told you, that is true, but local businesses get out-competed, but they are so much better. First, because local businesses reinvest in these communities because they're owned by people in the community who want to profit back. They spend their profits on other stores. And secondly, we told you, it leads to the better treatment of workers. Why? Because when Walmart comes in, Walmart doesn't care who lives there. Walmart cares about exploiting as much profit from the community as possible. But a local mom and pop store sees their neighbor walk in and apply for a job, they want to give them the best wages that they possibly can and still make a profit. I think the concern is very clear. Why then is displacement the thing to care about most in this round? Even if some people accrue marginal economic benefits who stay, it doesn't outweigh the devastation of displacement for thousands of people. I don't care if my toothpaste is $2 cheaper if I no longer have a home over my head.

The crucial flaw of opposition's case is that the new people who move in have different demands. If that's true, it proves the cost of living has increased because there's new demand. It proves the political capital will be used to crack down on cultures because these people have different demands. It proves the political capital will only be used to help the new buildings. And no, opposition, you cannot just find a new home. Because I'm a poor individual, it's very hard for me to put down a security deposit, put down first and last month's rent. I don't understand it. In their best case scenario, people are so poor they don't have roads. How are they going to afford to pay to find a new home? It's so clear. You should vote for the proposition. Thank you.

title: WSDC USA VS Philippines
description:
World School Debate Championship 2018 round 1
With Arabic Subtitles

I don't own this video, it belongs to its respectful owners. I'm ready to delete in any case of copyright infringement.
motion: This house believes that sports teams should be community-owned.

argument_units.text: Over a quarter million people flooded the streets to welcome back the Croatian national football team after the World Cup finals.

It's phenomena like these that we think demonstrate the power of sports to unite and define the community. With that, I'll do a couple of things in this speech. First, I'll provide our three-point model. Then, I'll provide our first two arguments. First, that sports are public goods that ought to be community-owned. And second, that community ownership protects community that ought to be community owned, and second, that community ownership protects community resources and betters community relations. Our second speaker will provide our third argument.

First on our model, we think sports clubs are non-profit in our world. This means revenue from ticket sales and merchandise would be reinvested back into the team instead of going into owners' private pockets. Secondly, residents of the city and in the surrounding area of a team's place of origin would be able to buy shares in the team's stock. We would also support a cap on shares to make sure that no one person or small group of people are able to have a disproportionate number of shares and disproportionate power. Our third point under this is that citizens who buy stock under our model would have voting rights over major long-term team decisions. This looks like moving locations, upgrading stadiums, ticket prices, and elections on new leadership. What this voting power does not include, however, are day-to-day sports management questions, like which players to draft or what plays to make. We think team managers and coaches hired by the board of directors would still have authority over actual competition. These look like teams like FC Barcelona and the Green Bay Packers.

With that, I'll go on to our stance for this round. We think the nature of sports is so impactful and intrinsic part of the community that it requires community control. Our stance is not that local communities need sports teams, rather they just own existing teams. We think that the team's impact on the community should be the primary focus for today's round because it is the community that has the most to gain or lose in the presence or absence of the sports team. Our first argument

is that on principle sports teams are public goods that should be controlled by communities. Our first point under this is that sports teams provide significant social benefits, but they still impose social costs and thus warrant community control. In general, when something is extremely important and its use imposes significant costs on individuals, we prefer things like government ownership because we want elected representatives rather than private actors to decide how to absorb or distribute those costs. This is why we have governments and non-corporations set tax rates, for example. Similarly, many private sports teams have a massive impact on the public, but the individuals in the community do not always consent to the costs that are associated with it. Stadiums and fields, for example, take up a lot of space, and the construction and location of these venues displaces residents to a large degree. For example, to build Tottenham Hotspur football stadium, many local homes would have to be demolished and displaced in order to make that happen. We think communities are much better placed to make decisions about these trade-offs with minimal impact to residents and businesses compared to private actors. Second point under this argument, because sports teams have a unique role in identity formation, they should be publicly owned. Sports shape social culture in a multitude of ways. First, the sports club serves as a point of congregation and a clear sense of identity for the community. People of all genders, races, education levels, religious backgrounds are all able to come together over sports, like we saw in Zagreb with the Croatian football team. Secondly, we think clubs enhance rivalries which create loyalties within communities both within each other and loyalties to the team. Third, organizations like sports are unique in that they are powerful in shaping communal identity and they claim to represent the community so they should be accountable to the community when they're doing these actions. We don't think one fringe billionaire should be able to have all of the control. Otherwise, individuals are simply governed by private interests and not themselves.

Our second argument is that community ownership better protects community resources and promotes community relations. But first... If sports is so integral to the community, then why historically have most community teams been sold off voluntarily? We think that this is not necessarily the heart of this debate, We're simply saying that community ownership is a good thing. We think there are wide factors that perhaps you could explain to us. We think communities have a very direct tie to the teams and this incentive would not exist on our side of the house. Our second argument explains this further, about how community ownership preserves local resources for the community. Private teams are well known for extorting cities for money. Billionaires and owners have very little loyalty to a particular city because they don't have to care about the city to get money out of them. It's because owners know they can get whatever they want by threatening to leave. This looks like cities being forced to give up stadium subsidies that are much higher than the cost of education within their cities without community consent. This also looks like things like favorable tax breaks to teams as well. We saw this happen in New York, for example. Direct and indirect subsidies to three major New York stadiums, Yankee Stadium, Citi Field, and the Barclays Center cost $867 million, while universal pre-K in the city would have only costed roughly $500 million. When these decisions about prioritizing sports over things like education are made by private actors, we think that harms the community much more. We think community-owned teams have a unique obligation to conserve public resources and they're thus more likely to balance support for sports versus other priorities like community well-being. Ultimately, when cities don't capitulate to owners demands, they lose the teams after spending millions of dollars on them. This looks like the Brooklyn Dodgers moving to LA, Clyde Bank FC moving to Wakefield, and the Sydney Swans moving to South Melbourne. We are principally opposed to that on our side of the house. Our second point under this is that local ownership of teams builds social capital and strengthens the community network. We think community-owned teams are much more likely to devote their resources to community efforts, like funding youth outreach programs, for example. It's because these teams are governed by local community members who directly benefit from these policies, so they are more likely to want community outreach as the incentive as to why they want to do this. This looks like FC Barcelona's Football Net program, which teaches kids about teamwork and perseverance through sports it reaches over 30,000 kids in Catalonia alone and especially low income individuals and it's all free of charge compare that to Arsenal sports camp which would cost you $1,600 a week and that money goes into the hands of
owners Stan Kroenke not the community because they're privately owned and next

point under this argument is that community ownership results in a greater buy-in to sports themselves. The community is much more likely to do things like volunteer for teams because they've literally invested in the team. We think the buy-in is empirically larger for community-owned teams like we see with the Green Bay Packers, for example. We see volunteers are very willing to work in sessions to the point where they're also willing to shovel snow in freezing temperatures to help out the team. It is this devotion to the team that we think is unique to community ownership because they're the ones that have this connection that private teams don't because owners don't make the effort to connect with the community. In contrast, the Dallas Cowboys are a privately owned team. And if the owner, Jerry Jones, asked for volunteers volunteers he'd be laughed at because the people know that the volunteer work they do only saves Jerry Jones a little bit of money and doesn't go back into the community. We think that additionally ticket prices are much more likely to become decreased on our side of the house. It's because private investors are profit motivated so they run sports like a business. This increases ticket price, this means increased ticket prices and selling elite luxury boxes for money. In contrast, community members have voting power, and they want to attend sporting games. So they have an incentive to keep ticket prices low and make games as accessible as possible to the large majority of the community. We think that sports have value because they foster civil society. They create networks of people that foster cooperation, common understanding, and the fulfillment of the human need for interaction. Thus, we are very proud to propose. I now welcome the first speaker.

The real world is not some Marxist fantasy land. Don't let side propositions, overly romanticized notion of sport, disguise the fact that professional sports teams require huge amounts of money and the rich individuals and corporations we defend give this money. We think that this is reflective of the fact that in history, many community-owned teams voluntarily sold those teams off in order to protect the sustainability of the sport.

What is our stance? One, we support things like status quo, where private individuals or corporations should be allowed to own teams. Two, we think communities can still own teams or buy into shares if individual people want to own it. We don't think we need to require them to do so. Two arguments at first speaker. One, why our policy is necessary to even have a sizeable sports industry and two, why corporations are more effective at keeping sports competitive. My second speaker will engage with the best case scenario side proposition where even if they can prove these two things are available on their side, why they increase rapid inequality and worse competitiveness. They have, in terms of rebuttal, they gave you two main ideas. Firstly, this principled idea about the public good of sports and secondly the last two arguments can be reduced to the idea about how private corporations know exploit communities while community ownership benefits.

First, their response to the idea of sport being a public good. Look, Mr. Speaker, these aren't mutually exclusive ideas. You can have a public good and still earn profit as well. We see this in things like electricity, which is clearly a public good. But many countries privatize electricity because they realize they can serve that public good while at the same time doing it more efficiently. That's what my arguments will show you. But even if they can show you some social costs, there are enormous social benefits, like the tourism, like the merchandising, like the increased publicity of your city. But we think they're pretty inconsistent because they're capping shares anyway, so their whole democratic principle is slightly undermined at the point when they're not actually including the whole community. And furthermore, no thank you, we think their view of fans is too parochial. FC Barcelona, Arsenal, the Green Bay Packers have global backing. We think they reduce the incentive of these people, no thank you, to cater to the global community. Lastly, in terms of harms, look, there's a social license to operate that most teams need to respond to because it affects the viability of the team. When the local people don't support them if they hurt them. That's their entire principal case dealt with. The second and third arguments, no thank you, is about exploitation of communities and subsidies to sports. We think this is an example of arguing by example. They've shown you singular instances, but not showing that this is systemically true. We show you that structurally, no thank you, there is very little incentive to do these abuses because people are likely to lose profit by the anger because people no longer buy. We give you the example of the Minnesota Timberwolves because when the Lakers left Minneapolis, the Minnesota Timberwolves came in. This shows you they don't have the same grip they want to talk to you about. No thanks. Their last argument was about social outreach. I will rebut this all throughout my case. It will be completely integrated. Moving on to my first argument about why this is necessary.

We think, first layer of analysis here, there is massive funding that professional sports teams require. Things like paying player salaries, coaching salaries, travel, training and health, maintenance of stadiums, marketing and advertising, as well as licensing fees for the names you use. We think in general, corporations or rich individuals are much better able to absorb these costs because of the enormous resources they have relative to most communities. But on the second level, no thank you, we think that owning professional sports is an extremely risky business that demands corporate ownership as a safeguard because they can absorb losses to buffer capital or credit. Four points of analysis here. No. First, corporations or rich people have excess money to invest and are in it for the long haul, as opposed to teams who respond to short-term incentives, so in short losses like in the past, they sold off these teams anyway. Secondly, in terms of financial hardship or recession, these corporations, no thank you, or rich individuals, have better ability to access credit or bridge loans because of their reputation with banks. No. Thirdly, this is also directly responsive to their idea about how individuals will volunteer. We think individuals will deprioritize sports if recession or financial hardships means they have to prioritize other aspects of their life, and they will cut their losses. We have similar examples. In 2016, in the English Premier League, seven clubs ran a loss which was cross-subsidized by profits from other industries that their owners had. What is going to happen on their side? We don't think they can reasonably expect people to take money out of their pension funds, their health insurance costs, and other costs they have to fund sports teams. Or in basketball in 2008, when the Detroit Pistons or the Cleveland Cavaliers reached the Eastern Conference Finals, even if those cities were hard to seek by recession, because on our side, corporate owners were able to fund the money to be off this. We think if they want to have a principle about the integrity of sport, no thank you, the sustainability of the sport is most important in this debate. We think these three layers already show why it's less sustainable because the potential money is redirected to other things that people need to prioritize. This hurts the team but also creates a vicious cycle of deprioritization because at this point where the teams start performing worse, there is less incentive for these volunteers to buy into that team and buy into that identity scheme. So if that's the thing they wanted to put out in terms of social outreach, that hurts them as well. Are the comparative corporations have safety nets or investors come to save the teams? That doesn't happen on their side, no thank you. Those three layers already show you why their side is not sustainable. But preemptively we want to make a distinction between things like sponsors and owners, because we recognize that side proposition can claim things like sponsors as well. The first thing we say is that owners invest stimulus money in the team whereas sponsors do not. This stimulus money is important in times where you need to do things like renovation
The reality of side opposition's case is this.

Private owners willing to sink a lot of money into the teams are necessary in order for these teams to be financially solvent, therefore teams are allowed to exist allowing for all the community benefits on our side of the house. We simply do not think that this is true. We tell you that when owners do sink a ton of money into the team, it is not for the express purpose of operating at a loss. And in fact, it is not those individual owners that incur the cost of their teams running at a loss. We tell you it is actually two actors that do that. First, these teams push the cost of their team running a loss onto actual governments by extorting cities for stadium subsidies when they're running a loss, when they're not making enough money, as we tell you on our side of the house. Second, let's just be clear. The debt that these private owners take on, they do not take on themselves. They take on that debt in the name of the team. So when Manchester United, owned by the rich Glazer family, takes on $660 million of debt, they are free to escape that debt by selling off the shares of Manchester United. The team is then left with that debt. These are not benevolent owners willing to take on massive losses in the name of owning a sports team. We don't really think that makes a whole ton of sense. These are owners looking to own, you know, glamorous sports teams and are willing to push all of those costs back onto the community. To them, sports is a business. To us, we think sports are a community public good.

Two questions in this speech before I introduce our third substantive argument. First, do communities have a principal right to own sports teams? And second, which side best benefits communities themselves? But first, do communities have a principled right to own sports teams? We told you that sports teams are fundamentally incredibly important to communities and often impose really strong involuntary costs and shape community identity. They told you a few responses to this. They first told you that we have some public goods like electricity owned by private actors. We don't think that's a good thing. We do not think that a private entity should be able, principally, to control all of the electricity in a city without any kind of community or government ownership. But even if you do think that privatization of electricity is a good thing, I don't know the last time that there were marches in the street rallying entire identities allowing the electrical infrastructure of a country. In contrast, just that last week, as we told you, over a quarter million people in the city of Zagreb rallied around the community sports team as a center point of their identity. We don't think that one fringe billionaire or corporation should be able to control these kinds of dialogues. We'll explain more about this in our third argument as well. Otherwise, if one fringe billionaire or corporation should be able to control these kinds of dialogues. We'll explain more about this in our third argument as well. Otherwise, if one fringe individual is basically allowed to control the narratives and identities of a city through ownership of a sports team, by doing things like allowing or not allowing

African American players in the United States to kneel on the field in protest of police brutality, we think that's incredibly abusive and fundamentally undermines the principles of democracy that we stand for on our side of the house. Furthermore, let's just clarify that when we say cap the number of shares people can own, we mean cap the number of shares that individual community members can own, not cap the number of shares the community as a whole can own. By doing this, we ensure that one rich individual doesn't buy up all the shares leading to all the problems we talk about on their side of the house. But furthermore they tell you that local fans are not the most important thing in this round and that global fans matter too. Yeah we think that FC Barcelona can't have many global fans but we tell you those fans are not the ones that are uprooted when a stadium demolishes their house. They're not the one that that team claims to represent the identities of and we do think that local fans are the most important. But they furthermore told you fans don't have the right to own these teams because fans are really bad at making decisions, they're super racist, and that enhances rivalries. We told you that to the extent that rivalries exist, say, between a Hindu team and a Muslim team, those rivalries are going to exist on either side of the house in a world of public or private ownership. We think that representation of those teams and encouraging more diversity of thought is much more likely on our side of the house when we have a lot of members of the community involved in these sports teams, not literally sometimes one individual or corporation shaping the entire narrative. And we reject the idea that billionaire corporations are way, way better at running sports teams at the point where people like Roman Abramovich, a rich Russian oligarch,

literally owns a sports team in the UK for the purpose of hiding money from the Russian government. We really contest this idea. But second, which side is better for communities? The extent of their engagement on this point that we brought up was that private teams are more sustainable. And that was basically their entire response. We don't think this really engaged with this, but we'll address it anyways. We told you, again, at the top of our case, that when these owners juicing a ton of money into the team, it's often not their own money. It's public money, and they don't take on the debt themselves. But we second tell you that actually shareholder sustainability is way, way better on our side of the house, because when people buy shares in a team, it's not a loan to the team that it then has to pay back. It's a direct investment. They told you that not all communities are going to be able to afford this. Well, take the example of AFC Wimbledon, a club in London, where the price of a share is £25 for an adult and £10 for a senior or a student. We don't think this is a ridiculous amount of money to spend. But even so, when fans are really, really dedicated to sports teams and are already taking on a lot of costs to, say, buy tickets and things like that, we don't think that these kinds of costs are ridiculous to take on. And furthermore, 7 out of the 8 most successful teams in the confederation of African football, not known for ridiculously wealthy communities, are community-owned. So we absolutely think that less-funded communities can own sports teams and be very successful.

But why would fans be willing to inject money into the team when the team is stagnating, when they have to prioritize other costs? We actually think that it is more likely that this is going to be a problem in privatized worlds because when fans don't have a direct stake in the team by virtue of the fact that they own it, they're less likely to support the team even through bad times. When the team is privately owned, that is actually less likely to happen. We think that people who have already made an investment to the team even through bad times. When the team is privately owned, that is actually less likely to happen. We think that people who have already made an investment to the team and have already bought in, as we told you in our argumentation, are more likely to support the team and it's actually going to be more likely to be successful on our side of the house. We actually tell you that in many cases, privately owned teams that are really, really struggling and almost going bankrupt often convert to community ownership, like with the Green Bay Packers, who were struggling to get by in the 60s and then sold off shares and became one of the most successful teams in the U.S. Now introducing our third substantive argument about how we better protect teams themselves is directly engages with a lot of their material. Our first idea under this is that we better the treatment of players and prevent exploitation. To individual and corporate owners, sports players are employees that are there to play the best they can and make them rich.

But in contrast to communities, members support players as fans and are much more likely to be interested in their health, their well-being, and other things like that. The comparative is this. Overwhelmingly white owners of sports teams extorting athletes of color, putting them in really physically laborious situations and then casting them aside, versus community-owned teams that actually care about them and are much more likely to protect their own well-being. But furthermore, we think that owners are structurally unrepresentative of communities and teams at the point where it costs millions and millions of dollars to own a sports team. This looks like the 15 of the 15 richest football owners in the UK, one being a woman. This looks like things like 32 all-white NFL owners telling African-American players, you can't kneel on the field and protest a police brutality or we're going to fine you. We think that's wrong. Our second idea under this is that community ownership ensures teams actually benefit from the financial resources they create. As per our model, community-owned teams are non-profit, meaning 100% of their profit goes back to the team. What does this mean? Both types of team can do things to increase revenue,
things like selling tickets, selling merchandise, and getting sponsorship deals.

The difference is that on-site opposition, when Arsenal has a sponsorship deal with Emirates, that just makes billionaire owner Stan Kroenke richer. He already has $8.3 billion. We don't think that he needs more. But when Real Madrid has a sponsorship deal with Adidas or Hugo Boss or Microsoft, all of that money goes back into the team, goes back into the community endeavors that they invested. Even if teams are marginally richer on their side of the house, we think that that money actually goes back into the team on our side. We're very proud to propose.

I would like to thank the second speaker and the opposition team for their speech. And I'd like to invite the opposition to . We think it's incredibly assumptive for Proposition to assume that poor teams will always be able to afford their sport teams just because they're core to their identity.

But my first speaker already told you, once healthcare costs go up, once food goes up, sports is the first to go, because I'd rather not have a team that not send my kids to school. Ultimately, we think even in their best case, right, and I'm going to engage that in my extension, where teams will always survive and will always be sustainable and that's being incredibly generous for them, it creates large amounts of inequality between teams and in the representation that is harmful.

We think ultimately, right, sports needs lots of money and corporations have lots of money. They cannot offer that on their side. Before my extension, I have multiple points of response towards the previous speakers. Firstly, right, they tell you that owners will always be exploitative and they give us a gross caricature of all owners, simply saying they don't care about their communities, they're awful people and we shouldn't make them richer. We don't think it analyzed what are the incentives that come with profit because we don't think profit is such a terrible incentive after all. We think they have to give structural reasons as to why owners will never care, owners are going to be disgusting and owners will always be abusive. First sub-level of rebuttal here then. They tell you with regard to community resources, right? We're going to uproot people from their homes, we're going to take people out of school, and we're going to make sure that as owners, we can't be incredibly abusive. Firstly, we think there's already incentive not to do that. Because if people from that community are always going to hate you because you take away things that are important to them, then you lose your fans. You lose important fan bases that will provide you ticket sales, that will wash your games. In these instances, we think there are all the extreme disincentives for that to happen. But B, even in the worst case, we think there are abilities for communities to resist. We don't think owners own all the resources to that community. And in the instance, for example, when the Seattle Supersonics could not provide a team with a stadium that was necessary, the team left. They didn't force anyone to give them a stadium, no thank you.

B. They tell you about community involvement. And because the community, they talk about things like ticket prices and the ability for people to exercise, the ability for people to have charities and things like that. Our first response there is again, there's incentive to do that because you want a growing fan base. But B. Even in the worst case, for example, the tickets do rise, I have two responses to that. Firstly, we don't think it's likely because you respond to supply and demand. If to the point the tickets are inaccessible, then you want to lower those prices because you want people to go to your stadium. But B, we think in the point that they do rise, we think that they do not calculate the cost of what a team may mean. So rising ticket prices might mean we have to pay for more player equipment. Rising ticket prices might mean we have to pay for our players' salaries. And if their goal is to be competitive as well, that cannot happen if we have a clouded view as to what that means. But last response onto this. They tell you they will have more diversity, ignoring our response. We think on either side, right? We can have racism, we can have discrimination, and that is regrettable. But what are the best disincentives to counter this? Communities can still be racist. We think a team like Chelsea, which hated a lot of their African American players, and wanted Sam, their Israeli manager, even if he did well, because he was Israeli. title: WSDC | Western | R2 - Wales v USA
description: A video from The International Debate Education Association
motion: This house prefers industrial unions over workplace unions.

argument_units.text: industrial unions are better for unions' rights, workers' rights, and within this I'm going to be using the sub-point of why workplace unions are less effective for the representation of workers. But before I define what these industrial unions would look like, let our stance to the opposition be clear. We do not deny that both workplace and industrial unions cannot exist together, and we do believe that both of them are important for the workforce. However, fundamentally, we will explain to you why industrial unions can create industry-wide change, and this makes mass political action easier, and therefore industrial unions would be more preferable. So a workplace union is a union that only involves the workers of one specific company.

And so these unions would then therefore tend to focus on directly negotiating with the management of that individual company. And later in my speech, I'm going to highlight how this in itself is problematic for the wellbeing of the workers and how it's less effective in implementing change for them.

And by contrast, an industrial union is a union with workers from the entire industry. And industrial unions more often will try and focus on trying to implement industry-wide standards for workers' rights, rather than just negotiating with individual companies. And it's this meaningful mass change that truly positively affects the lives of workers, and this is why we find it more preferable. A burden of proof in this debate is that we will prove to you that industrial unions

are more effective in protecting the rights of workers and overall improving the efficiency of the industry as a whole. And so this leads me on to our argument on why industrial unions are better for the rights of workers. So to provide a mechanism for the workplace union, we think that it works by having the workers, like I said, negotiate with a company. But ultimately with this mechanism, it's the management making the decisions, not the workers. that in mind, our first substantive argument is that we increase the effectiveness of unions. There are three reasons why we get people to buy in and join unions on our side of the house. Number one, recruitment is significantly easier on our side of the house. It is more likely that you're going to join a union if it's someone that's in your workplace, i.e. a co-worker or someone that you trust that is coming and recruiting you, rather than someone that's like an external marketing agent from the larger industrial union. Secondly, on our side of the house, we get much more specific messaging. People within the union are speaking to your specific issues as opposed to broad industry problems. So if, for example, you work for a manufacturing plant and the biggest concern is safety, you don't want to hear about hours and different things like that. You want to hear about safety. So messaging on our side of the house is more persuasive and more compelling because it's specific to the workplace. Finally, I think it's because you're more likely to see change quickly. When you have workplace unions, you're more likely to see immediate returns. This is number one, because like I said before, there's less red tape and bureaucracy that exists. But finally, for change to happen on their side of the house, there's to be large levels of buy-in i.e workers across different companies have to come together and agree that a problem is an issue strike for that problem or lobby for that problem for that to be solved that requires far more work than our side of the house so if people are more likely to see returns at a faster pace they were more likely to stay within the union at that point we not only get better recruitment but people stay in the unions on our side of the
