Even on their side when tourists are well-intentioned, they still cause harms because of their presence. There's things like environmental degradation from walking over a path too often, poor sanitation, pollution from flights and cruises. This simply happens because a large number of people are in a place that is not designed for them. Some of the world's best surfing beaches have been made unsurfable because of the construction of ocean-side property that impact wave breaks. Now, also, tourists must live somewhere, eat somewhere, do something with their days. This means we have to build airports, hotels and so on. These are built on forested land or local communities, not on empty land. This impacts the environment and locals. Now, onto how tourism

impacts local culture. No, thank you. So culture is exploited as well as the environment because tourists fill places like churches, which means that locals who actually want to worship there cannot fit in. You know, they have to get tickets and so on. Even if they can access it, they have a private ability to enjoy them spiritually because they're covered in graffiti, they're full of people, as I told you. Even if they can access it, there is pressure to bastardise local culture, turning it into a commercial, unsellable product for tourists. For example, in Hawaii, luau celebrations have traditionally been reserved for very important occasions, like the birth of a child, like victory in a war. But now, multiple are thrown per night as an exotically branded party, aimed at tourists with sexualised waitresses. This is extremely degrading for a local whose culture is being turned into a product. This happens everywhere. Japanese kimonos being turned into a vessel to get extra tips. Traditional healing practices like massage being fetishised and serving as an entrance into sex tourism. This is incredibly harmful. Why should you weigh this? Firstly, on the environment and built culture, you must remember that people go to incredibly beautiful places, places that are incredibly important to humanity, the Great Barrier Reef, the Vatican, and so on. We have an obligation to future generations to protect these incredibly important places by not completely degrading them. Opposition harms them significantly. No, thank you. On culture, these are places with historic and important and ongoing culture, particularly to Indigenous people. Opposition is essentially resurrecting colonialisation as they allow large numbers of foreigners to come in and exploit culture and land for a fun summer abroad. I'll take a point for a move on my next substantive. If you are promising to take vandalism and graffiti, you might have to place regulations that could be used at some point. Firstly, there are far too many tourists to place regulation. We see in the status quo that vandalism already happens because there are simply too many tourists to effectively replace. Since we have less tourists, the police resources are stretched less thin. We get better management of graffiti. And secondly, even if you known by that, there is still harm by tourists physically being there, even if they're well-intentioned, as I told you, you still get those harms.

Now, on to economics. So, opposition is likely going to run a case that tells you tourism is really important for local economies. I'm going to explain why that's not the case, why it's actually harmful. So, firstly, on the actual scale of benefits that tourism brings to a local country. Many foreign tourists prefer to stay at Western-style hotels, you know, go to Western-style resorts and theme parks, no thank you, because they feel safe there, because they feel accommodated there, you know, they trust the food and so on. These institutions are run by large multinational companies like the Crown Prize of West Anglia, which is run by IHG, an international company, and these companies are based offshore offshore they're headquartered offshore they uh you know know how to exploit tax loopholes therefore in general the largest amount of money does not go to the local country no thank you the comparative is our auction system where the money goes straight to the local government there's likely to be a very large benefit so we get a good amount of money on our side secondly on housing crisis so as more workers are required to fill jobs in tourist areas they move into these big cities and they push locals out. Also, as tourists with more money are able to move into these areas, they pay more for things like Airbnbs, which pushes locals out. It becomes virtually impossible to find a place to live as an ordinary person living in these cities. They're forced out of the city, they're forced into homelessness in places like Barcelona, Byron Bay and Brighton. Next, inflation. Wealthy tourists with lots of money to spend and desire to spend it are willing to pay far more than locals for basic things like medicine, food and groceries and so on. This causes local businesses to push up the prices to match which makes it much harder to live and it outstrips the growth in wages caused by increased
standards of living to the extent they exist. And finally, tourists have an incentive to

go to businesses because of advertising. They're only there for a week, they've never been to the place, and they're likely never going to go back to, for instance, a restaurant. This means locals get worse services overall, since they're not designed for repeat customers, they're designed for one-off customers. Now, on to the biggest economic harm, which is economic dependency. I'll take the point first, though. Again, broadly, this isn't true. Tourists obviously have to share things like the metro system to get around. When we were in Paris, we used the local metro system. There simply aren't alternatives to tourists. But also to the extent that the government is likely to spend more money on these services at the cost of things designed for locals, since tourists, as I told you, can pay more. So the government's incentive is to cater for them, not for locals. Now, onto the key economic impact, which is economic dependency. This is what happens when 30% of your economy is reliant on tourism. So, firstly, your economy is far more vulnerable to shocks outside of your control that impact the number of tourists significantly. This is things like terrorist attacks, things like global pandemics, things like changing international relations, even just... No, thank you. The changing social pressures of where to go, what is popular on Instagram. This means that you can't control the number of tourists you get, this is a large economic shock. This is also true every single year, it's the seasonality of tourism. You know, people go in the summer, people go when they have holidays, which means that for half of the year, workers and businesses have no income stream, a very little income stream, which means that they are unemployed or it's far harder to manage. Now, why is it particularly nefarious? Because tourism kills other industries. Because it is so lucrative for six months of the year, local capital flows significantly into tourism and talent at the cost of other industries in the region. So it's even more dependent. Next, inflation really hurts other industries because at the point at which, you know, the resources you need to run your business, at the point at which paper becomes more expensive because your currency is implanted, it's harder to run other businesses. And finally, environmental damage and congestion affect your productivity.
If your metro ride takes an hour to get to work instead of 30 minutes because it's clogged up with tourists, this means you're less productive.

Why can we successfully diversify? One, we get money from auctioning these permits and we still have money from tourism in the off-season, which means that we have the money to diversify. Next, the government is forced to diversify. They can't milk the short-term cash cow of tourism. There is political pressure to find other businesses to go into since people still want jobs. And finally, there are other industries in all countries that can receive this amendment. We're not going to say what they are, but for instance, things like fishing, agriculture, sea trade routes, manufacturing, whatever, there are huge other industries that can go into. Particularly in Western countries like Paris, like Rome, where obviously there are other investments that can happen. We support diversification. We are less reliant on tourism. So proud to propose.

Perfect. Maybe a place like London might be fine the moment that you have a limit on tourists. But what happens to countries like Seychelles? What happens to countries like Sri Lanka? Because realistically, we have a couple of garment factories but nothing much else. To these countries, tourism is not a choice, it is a necessity. It is something that keeps these countries afloat. From the person on the street selling seashell necklaces to the mid-level manager that runs a hotel, it's the lifeblood of these countries. They do not provide us with an alternative. Diversification is just asserted into this debate. Therefore, we think we are the only side that cares about the most vulnerable. A couple of things in characterization, set up, before I move on to my responses and finally my substantive. Firstly, I want to characterize that deterioration of these tourist sites is something that is inevitable, whether that be to climate change, where, for example, Venice is sinking, not because of tourists, but because of a rise in ocean levels, but also because these tourist sites are a place where rebuilding and repairing is something that always occurs. Take, for example, the Great Wall of China, where although it's considered to be a part of the Qing dynasty, it was actually mostly built in the Ming dynasty because it keeps getting rebuilt. Understanding this, we think that the process of rebuilding and keeping these sites maintained and up-to-date is something that happens better on our site when they are better funded, cared for, and given the attention that they deserve. But secondly, I want to point out that their characterization is very unrealistic because both sides have self-regulation incentives. Because if Machu Picchu is destroyed to the point where no one can come there, then obviously no one's going to want to visit Peru and they lose out on the cash cow that they obviously had. Meaning that on our side, governments won't be stupid. They're going to impose regulations to make sure that these places can be preserved to some degree. On to set up then, a couple of things. Firstly, I want to point out that this is a debate about volume, and they need to prove to us why exactly limiting the number of tourists significantly is not only good for the economy, but is the tipping point for all these things that they claim to essentially save these sites. But on top of this, this debate is about a range of places. As much as it is about places like Athens or London, it is also a debate about places like Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Costa Rica, seashells,

countries that depend on people entering these places in order to survive. They need to lay out a plan for these countries, how they're suddenly going to diversify, why all the people won't be left starving. They haven't done that. We think that these are terrible. But secondly, what's our counter-model in this debate? We can impose countless numbers of regulations, that be crowd-organizational control measures through ticketing or imposing time limits, that be incentivizing good behavior through social media and awareness campaigns, that be safety measures to protect degradation and damage, like, for example, better support structures in Machu Picchu, protective stone coverings in the Coliseum and rebuilding these areas. We'd also have regulations in the cities to prevent for the worst excesses to locals, where, for example, Madrid has certain streets reserved only for locals, or maybe on price caps on Airbnbs and such. A couple of things in response before my argument.

Three things. Firstly, they say that tourism is inherently exploitative and people act in irresponsible ways. We think that tourists are being educated and improved, particularly because of social media, where people are increasingly aware of the detestable stag culture that needs to be avoided. But on top of this, we can support things like fines and regulation. Their only response in the POI to this is to say that surely regulation won't work because the police is stretched too thin. Why can we not ramp up the police then? Why can we not pay for better surveillance services? Why can we not beef up the ability to protect these areas? Regulation can work. Secondly, they say that you commercialise these places and this is inherently degrading. I want to flip this argument very quickly because if these places are fetishised and isolated, the solution is greater globalisation. Tourism solves the fetish object. Make people look at this culture, see the people living there and understand it. Tourism solves the fetishization. It does not cause it. Firstly, on why we are better for economic development. And secondly, on why we better preserve these sites. Firstly, on why we are better for economic development, and secondly, on why we better preserve these sites. Firstly, on why we are better for economic development. Premise. Prior to the advent of tourism-based economies, these destinations were extremely impoverished, and tourism was brought out as a necessity. Why? These are the people who this debate is most applicable to. This then creates an incentive for more local businesses, especially those unrelated to the tourism industry, for example, say, a restaurant in the region, to set up because more people have more disposable income to make use of those services. Why then, given that we have more money for governments, does this benefit translate to a national level? Because increased tax revenue from the increased income of local communities means that we have more tax revenue to pay for the people, but also we have access to foreign currency, and this is good, because access to foreign currency and the transition to local currency means that you have more foreign reserves in your bank, in your government's bank, which means that you're more stable and you attract more investment, but also you're able to set up state enterprises and things like touristic as tourism sites, national parks and cultural centers that directly earn money from tourists. Government spread this money. The initial investment would be used to grow tourism further and the secondary incentive will also be to spread the benefits further where diversification now is possible because you have the funds to do so and politically governments are going to want to do this as well because diversification is likely something that is popular. Why is this exclusive? Because these benefits only manifest through large injections of money into the economy as opposed to small ones. Because on their side, even if they get like a couple injections far and few apart, they still don't have the amount of foreign currency required to establish your local currency as a strong one in order to attract investors and such. Moving on then to my second argument on why we're better for the preservation of these sites. Premise. title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY03 Round15   Zimbabwe vs Netherlands
motion: This House believes that major tourist destinations should significantly limit the number of tourists that can visit.

argument_units.text: This is just Mason's time. Thank you. I'll begin my speech in 3, 2, one. To be a Brazilian woman living in the heart of Rio means that more than just fancy tourist aesthetics and surf life over anything, it means an increase in price of your children's baby formula because there's nothing you can do about it. It means making ultimatums between keeping your only home and having to sell it off to greedy capitalist faces in order to feed your family. It means ending up like the children in Bali competing for drops of water. It means having to grapple with the idea that the tourist market makes a joke out of your suffering and the living proof of that walks across your favela every day in millions just to take a photo of it.

Proposition says when it gets this terrible, we ought to take immediate action. I will argue, one, on principle, secondly, on the economic harms of the standard of living, and my second speaker will extend on the extended harm of tourism. But our two points on set-up.

On the count of the model, what do we look at? We say our policy is two-pronged. Firstly, we significantly limit by placing caps on attendance in various ways. We say, firstly, by restricting numbers to entry. We do this in just the same way Lord Howie Island in Australia restricts the islands to 400 people per night as of 2019. But secondly, through pre-bookings and specific tourist restrictions, right? We say we allow certain individuals at each point in time to enter major tourist destinations and make travel-specific visas to that very major tourist destination. But on the second layer, we say we aggressively promote other tourist destinations. We say we do this through the increased advertisements of smaller tourist destinations, but secondly, through promoting virtual tourism. We say in the same way Thievelu did this when the island was under imminent threats of sinkage. We say this is something that is important. But why then do we think this is the best and the only form of regulation? We say historically, due to the direct conflict that exists between the very purpose of tourism, which is to invade the natural space and be its parasite, and the core function of regulation, which is to limit invasion in one way or another, be it banning snorkeling in Guantanamo, be it the jail time for noise in Venice, or be it the banning of Airbnbs and hotel construction in Barcelona. We say that the governments have been unable to regulate without taking away from the adventure of tourism in itself. We say significant limitation, however, is unique in its ability to simply reduce the number of people that can invade this particular space. We say that's something that's important. So first, let's talk on principle. But before we do that, let's talk about a little bit of some pretext here.

We say that there's a long-standing history of tourism that has scarred and violently struck at the souls of locals within major tourist destinations. We say that this has served as the impetus for new untapped levels of hate and vitriol towards mass tourism by these locals. We say that the hate is closely tied to the idea of having too many tourists, and it conjures up feelings of unsafety and anger. We say in Spain, locals have been gathering up at tourist sites to throw stones at those particular locals, at those particular tourists. We say in Bali, we've seen violent protests and violent protests erupting at the end of the day, right? What then becomes the premise here? We say that the mass existence of tourists in the land of locals is a triggering and a frightening scene. We say government's responsibility in this instance should be to significantly reduce in order to put those people's minds at ease. What's the claim therein? We say the claim of this principle therein is two-pronged. One, we say that there is government obligation towards responsiveness, right? But secondly, we say that there is proactiveness of the government in response to the civil uproar that is occurring. What's the wash here? Why do we think there are no pragmatic benefits that are likely to materialize on their side? Because we say the tourism industry in itself is going to face severe damage in future because of this vigil. We see that people are already scared to travel to these areas, particularly because of the anger that's already there. So we think at the moment in which you don't resolve this, we don't see a world in which the pragmatic benefits they are going to argue for are going to materialize in the long term. So what do we want you to note critically? Note that we value the paternalistic utilitarian role of government in the instance where the populace can rationalize this decision. But in a world, however, where the people are greatly emotionally traumatized, where the people are hurting, where the people are bleeding, we think that government has to value putting the minds of those particular people at ease. They have to value then helping those particular people, right? What then becomes the proof of outcome here here we say in the instances that we don't follow this principle we think we then see followers of like mass citizen discontent right we see a lot of civil disarray because a lot of people are generally angry about the ideas and everything that's been going on i think that's something that is terrible but principally on its own right why is it important to follow this principle? Because you feel trust in your state, you say you feel the discontent and you fulfill that discontent of citizens who've been always feeling like the government has been not acting towards these things, right? Principally, those people feel safe and they feel like, you know, the state has fulfilled their obligation to the people. And we say that in itself is something that is very important that we ought to preserve.

But the second argument is on why significant limiting in itself in improving the standard of living. But before I take that, let me take a few more. If there's already so much fear for tourists traveling to these locations, why are we not going to see a gradual drop-off in the number of tourists? Why do we need to impose these strict government restrictions? So, I think we've already spent a long time explaining why that's something that's necessary. I don't think that's necessarily relevant. But when we talk about the significant limiting in improving the standard of living, what's the premises here? We say that over-tourism has harmed the standard of living for locals. We say that the locals have been priced out of the market, and this is manifested in multiple ways. One, we say it's manifested in the skyrocketing of prices for basic necessities. Notice how locals are forced to live on less than the bare minimum. They have lack of access to cheap food, clothing for your children. E.g., we saw this in the Bahamas, where there's a 47.5% increase in prices in every tourist season for them. And these prices are only getting worse and worse. Why is this so? Because one, there's an influx of tourists that jack up the demand and cause demand-pull inflation. But secondly, because tourists are generally perceived as financial stable people. And so companies generally have an incentive to increase prices so as to capitalize on the profits of as much as possible, right? But secondly, we say that locals are subject to forced displacement. We say that the rental prices and the housing costs are pushed up significantly, making it difficult for locals to often live in those areas. In New York, an urban tourist-heavy city, they average up to 80% more in housing costs making it difficult for locals to often live in those areas. In New York, an urban tourist-heavy city, they average up to 80% more in housing costs compared to other neighboring cities such as Jersey City. This happens because the demand for housing by tourists is often pushing out those particular... forcing a lot of landowners to maximize their profit by changing their business models from orienting towards the local market to orienting towards the tourist market to orienting towards the tourist market and pushing out those particular locals. We think secondly, we think locals are getting bought out of their houses. They prey on the despise of these particular locals for that money and use that land to then develop more tourist attractions that way they can benefit off of profit.
How is this harmful? Because we say people get displaced en masse to worse off areas. We say areas without functional surrounding essential services.

Areas like hospitals for healthcare and schools for education. We say that this hurts the locals. Weigh this harm on its self-amplifying nature. We say because tourism continues to expand and send people into even worse off areas, it means that people keep on getting worse and displaced even more and more. And this is something that is generally harmful. But lastly, we say the outpricing of locals renders that employment contracts useless at the end of the day. This is because the minimum wage jobs that these people are earning barely cover the high cost of living in these touristified areas. This is worse for lowly paid workers in the appendaging industries because this continues the price increase versus like the low wages continues to make them suffer within these areas. but how then does significantly limiting deal with this on the comparative note here one we say significantly limiting deals with overall pricing because there's no demand pool inflation so we think because there are less people we think the prices are much less but secondly we say that the businesses reduce like prices in order to cater to those local people because that's where their most that their profit base relies right to say that because now we've got more locals and locals are more more profitable like markets to invest into we're likely going to reduce our like prices to engage those people right but secondly we say deals with displacement because landlords have no incentive to increase the rent as like the main consumer base again are locals right but secondly we say airbnbs and other housing structures are likely not going to change the ways they do their structures because they understand how they're going to be able to attain more money from that particular consumer base. We say what's better for those particular individuals who are better for the locals, and we think that this is something that is incredibly important on our side. Proud to vote.

Proposition refuses to acknowledge that for many people, tourism is their livelihood. In Bangkok, the industry supports a salary of 50 million people. The population depends on it to pay for their rent, their groceries, and their children's education. Propaganda has to defend a large part of the population losing their job with no alternative. I am so proud to oppose.

In my speech, I will prove two things. Firstly, why tourism is the only viable economic stimulus of the region. And secondly, why tourism is crucial for regional development, such as infrastructure. But first, let's start with framing.

What do we think that these tourist destinations look like? We think most of these destinations enormously benefit from tourism economically. So, for example, in my tourism directly or indirectly brings in 70% of the GDP on the island. Limiting tourism means robbing people from their income and their opportunities to build a future.

We think it is likely that alternative measures will be implemented to combat the negative effects of tourism because the local population wants to keep their environment clean and tidy for their own enjoyment. So this looks like promoting off-season travelling more and having security on heritage sites. We see that this is worked in, for instance, the Colosseum, where more security has significantly decreased the amount of tourists that have attempted to vandalise the walls.

Okay. No, thank you. Now, quickly moving on to rebuttal. Firstly, on that principle, I just want to note here that it fully relies on the practical outcome of the debate. As in, they say that the reason that the government should care about this is because the population is hurting really bad. At the point that we prove to you that the population is hurt more on their side, we also take this principle. And then on the practical argument about the economy, I want to note that what we see is that often only the tourist products are inflated. So for example, the restaurant prices are inflated, but groceries aren't. Hotel prices are inflated, but homes aren't. And we tell you that even if the prices are high, on our side, there is a salary to pay these prices to begin with. On our side, there is none. Before I move on to the first argument, I will take a break.

Is it not the reason why other industries like factories and farms can't develop? It's because there is tourism and there is no way for these industries to come in to develop these areas. There are structural reasons why other industries cannot develop, and this is what I will explain in my second argument. For example, they don't have the natural resources. For example, they don't have the space.

title: WSDC 2024 Serbia   DAY03 Round17   Finland vs Austria
motion: This House believes that major tourist destinations should significantly limit the number of tourists that can visit.

argument_units.text: By limiting the number of the tourists, it is the only way to save the lives of the locals. In the best case, tourists are annoying, but in great quantities, they are a scourge to the earth. Two arguments in the proposition case. Firstly, improving the life of the locals. And secondly, reshaping travel culture and combating climate change. Now, into the frame. We tell you, PAC, that the locals are the most important stakeholder in the debate. Because they are the people that still have to live in these major tourist destinations even when the tourists leave. They are the people that pay taxes to maintain these destinations. They are also the people that are building these cities throughout generations. They are, most importantly, the people that will have to stay there and deal with whatever consequences the tourists leave afterwards. Therefore, I urge the panel to care the most about locals in this debate. So now, how can we win this debate? Two things. First, we can prove to the panel that locals are better on our side of the house. Or then we can prove to the panel that locals are better on our side of the house, or then we can prove to the panel that climate change is significantly combated on our side of the house. Both ways, by proving either, we will win this debate.

So now into the model. We tell you that on our side of the house, we are proposing a model where tourists will have to apply for an access pass to come to these cities. They will have to pay for an access fee that these host governments can choose themselves. And this fee will then be used to maintain these destinations after these tourists leave. And there will only be a limited amount of passes that are solved within a single time frame.

So now, into the first argument. So we tell you, Pam, that on our side of the house, we're directly improving the life of locals. What do we mean by this? Three parts in this argument. Firstly, we're telling you that we're directly reducing the disturbance of locals. What do we mean by this? Three parts in this argument. Firstly, we're telling you that we're directly reducing the disturbance of locals. What do we mean by this? We tell you that in excessive amounts of these tourists, there are flooding restaurants, there are flooding streets, there are flooding bars, there are flooding every single part of the city. This makes the lives of the locals extremely hard because it's very hard for me to get to a hospital, for example, to see my mother, if there's an excessive amount of crowd near the Colosseum and I have to get through the Colosseum to the hospital. It's not convenient for the locals. It's not great for the locals. Moreover, these tourists leave a significant amount of trash and litter and all kinds of disposable material behind. Moreover, they also consume much more than these locals. They consume much more plastic. They consume six times the amount of water than the locals consume. And this is not sustainable for these major tourist destination cities. Moreover, there is noise. There's significantly more noise with overcrowdings, with just, you know, the people walking through the streets or the crowd shouting when they see the Eiffel Tower because it's just so great for them. And even, no, you know, the people walking through the streets or the crowd shouting when they see the Eiffel Tower because it's just so great for them. And even, no, thank you, and even if we do not take these examples into consideration, just because I live in an apartment building and my rich neighbor landlord is renting their apartment continuously to tourists, when they continuously rent their Airbnb to tourists that do not care about regulation, that party every single night. It's very hard for me as a student to study for my medical school entrance exam. We tell you that all of these are directly reduced on our side of the house, because just by limiting the sheer quantity of tourists that visit, all of these problems are already significantly reduced on our side of the house. But now, secondly, we're also reducing the indirect harms that these tourists cause to these major tourist destinations. We tell you that these tourists, with their share quantity, they are directly pushing up the prices of all services. This means, for example, food prices, gas, every single thing that you can imagine are going up because there's so many of these tourists in these places that you know Everyone can just charge so much more but we tell you that this still does not benefit the locals Even if opposition tells you that why we tell you that the only people that are actually Benefiting from these are already the wealthy we tell you that it's only the rich landlords, those who have owned this property for already 100 years or big international or regional corporations. It's only these three kinds of people that actually benefit from there because they already own this property in these major, you know, tourist destinations. They have property there and they can rent them with extremely high prices to these local businesses. We tell you that these people will rent with a high price, and this makes the people who actually are in these places, these local business owners, they have to sell at a significantly higher price if they want to make any kind of return or profit from this. And this, again, makes the lives of those who don't do this much harder because you have to now pay at a much higher price. But you don't have this because you are a local. And we tell you that only tourists are able to do this because they are only temporary. They come for a fixed amount of one, two days. They're able to afford this because they think that, okay, I'm going to pamper myself for two days, pay a bit more. It doesn't matter for them. But it matters for these locals that have to stay there even when the tourists leave. That is not true in the status quo. The status quo is so that these tourist destinations, these cities are flooded with tourists everywhere. There is no local or tourist quarter because all of this is a tourist quarter. Everywhere in the city, there is so much demand from the tourists that all of the prices are spiked up. Moreover, we also tell you that this problem manifests even more when you look at housing prices. Because I already gave you the example of people renting more and more Airbnb's because they know that hotels cannot accommodate they simply cannot accommodate all of the people that want to go to paris that want to go to rome that want to go to bernice it's simply they know that they have they can you know rent more and more airbnbs at you know limited amount of time it's for them it's even more profitable to maybe keep them for a few days without anyone leaving living there then you know they are able to do that and you know still rent at a much higher price and, you know, still rent at a much higher price because when they know, when someone rents it, it's so much more profitable this way than to rent for a longer period of time for, you know, a local.

I tell you that on our side of the house, these problems are significantly less. And thirdly, I also tell you that we're preserving identity and cultural heritage. We tell you that on our side of the house, we're directly reducing the harm caused to natural sites like we see in France, we have the La Salle caves, where that had to be closed, they had to be shut down because the enormous amount of tourists that visit us day in, day out because of the excessive carbon dioxide that was, the humidity of people, the human-caused erosion. These are all factors that cannot be, that
simply cannot be reduced through other measures. And there's also not to mention vandalism,

you know, trashing, littering, taking pieces off these natural sites. And this cannot be reduced with any other means. This cannot simply be done by, you know, adding more police, because there's so many people, one police or a few more police won't do anything. We tell you that only by reducing the number of people can we actually do something if it is, for example, humidity or excessive carbon dioxide. And our side of the house is telling that it's extremely important for the locals because they have value to them. If I'm a person who grew up every day walking past the Eiffel Tower, every day you know all of my childhood memories are attached to this one place, when this place represents part of my national identity or something that I have national pride towards, it is not fair for these locals to be ripped away from this and even if you don't believe that this is beneficial for the locals, we also give you this alternative point of view that this is also beneficial for the tourists if you take good care about them. We tell you that tourists will want to come as long as the Eiffel Tower is there, as long as the Eiffel Tower is in good condition, and on their side of the house, because they do not want to limit, because they do nothing to stop the deterioration of these, tourists will, in the future, not even want to come to these places, and therefore, even whatever beneficial economic impacts that they are providing

will not happen. So now to summarize three parts in my speech that I've told you. Firstly, we're reducing direct harms to these locals. Noise, overcrowding, traffic jams, everything. Secondly, we are pushing down the prices because we're making these economies reshape around locals and not the prices that toys give. And thirdly, we're also giving them back the right to these natural sites. And therefore, life is better on our side of the house. I urge the panel to vote for us.
Panel, we on-side off don't limit the people, we limit harms.

In my speech I will bring up two major arguments. Why there is no alternative industry and second, why this will lead to mass unemployment and economic regression. In our second speech we will explain how this motion leads to massive loss of current and future infrastructure. But first some responses regarding the quantity of tourists versus the quantity of tourists. On our side, we still can have and likely will have regulations and incentives for tourists to behave well. These also rebut all of your points. Note, panel, that the proposition cannot claim we have no regulations on our side of the house. We simply do not regulate the number of tourists, which does not mean we do not regulate certain behaviors. In the status quo, we see that regulation of behaviors is happening. A. Barcelona is banning Airbnbs, which rebutts all their point about housing prices. B. As we have seen in Copenhagen and Japan, they are offering perks like free lunches for tourists who use public transportation, who participate in cleanup activities, or support local businesses. Also, it rebuts the whole environment part. D, or we see that they are limiting the hours where alcohol can be bought to reduce bad behavior. E, we also see that there are stricter regulations and are being implemented, and there are increased fines for littering or damaging cultural sites, which are directly used for resuscitation or upkeep the very same. So these regulations are voting issues and popular among locals, which is the reason they are implemented.

Moving up to my first argument, the lack of viable alternative industries. We see this because of geographic constraints. Most of these countries simply do not have anything else to offer. So they have no minerals to mine, they have infertile land, they have multiple regions that are hard to access. Prop would need to explain why any ship is feasible and most countries would have the geographical ability. So second, there's no incentives for companies to establish themselves in these regions. A, in many countries you have comparatively higher tax rates and workers' rights. For example, Ireland, which is a tax hub and has very low tax rates compared to any other European country or Asian country. B, therefore, it is very easy for companies to move to a place where they don't pay taxes, like Ireland, for example, or Bangladesh, where you don't have any workers' rights. So in countries like Italy, it is way harder to establish yourself. Our third point is investor trust. Because there are tourism-specific investments, you have first a lack of high-speed internet, you have lack of heavy-duty roads, and your priorities easy and quick to build roads for tourist purposes. You have lack of industrial ports because beaches were prioritized. Four, you have localized skills and knowledge gap. Hali specializes workforce which needs to be re-educated to fit in a new industry. A. The workforce in these tourist-centric regions has developed skills specifically tailored to the tourism industry. Tour guides, hotel managers and cultural event coordinators possess skills that are directly tied to local tourism. So B. There is a lack of knowledge for new sectors. Developing alternative industries would require new skills and expertise that the local population currently lacks, for example, programming, mining or fishing. This is expensive and relies on the cooperation of the local people which is not guaranteed. We believe the fear of economic instability bothers the willingness and the ability of individuals to invest in learning skills. This means even if taxes and worker's rights would not be the problem, the local infrastructure and population will. We think it is unlikely that government should be able to attract and lobby companies and investors to move there. Historically, they are a huge competitive disadvantage against other countries who have worked on this relationship for decades and also they have way less to offer them because infrastructure, as I already mentioned, wasn't built and the knowledge was focused on tourism. This means that investors are not going to want to invest before these accommodations are built. And without investment, it is unlikely they will be able to build them. Because at the same time, the tourist countries are missing out on their biggest income, which is tourism. Especially if we look at the investment on a comparative, we are losing out on massive amounts of money. Currently, there is high investor trust in these regions because they have huge amounts of people coming in and the direction is increasing. Before I move on to my second argument, I will take it away.

Argument two, massive unemployment and economic regression. How does this happen? We have direct job losses. The tourism industry directly employs millions in sectors such as hospitality, transportation and retail. Significantly reductions in numbers mean significant amount of people will lose their jobs. There are less customers, less visitors, and less clients. So we also have indirect job losses because tourism supports numerous of other industries such as agriculture, this means food supplies for restaurants, and manufacturing goods for tourists. The loss of tourism would ripple through the supply chain. Also, third point is financial burden on the state. We would have massive unemployment benefits and business support needed. The state would need to provide unemployment benefits to displaced workers and provide business and previous business owners. This would strain public finances. This would require reallocating budget resources and impacting public services like healthcare and education. This is especially bad at the same time you significantly limit the biggest income source of the government, which is tourism. So, then we have a psychological and social impact. The fear and uncertainty. Even a slow implementation of tourist limits would create fear and uncertainty among the local population, undermining confidence in economic stability. This is crucial because the development of new industries is dependent on people spending money on this new industry and supporting its development. Why will this not be the case? A. People fear the unknown. They have worked in tourism for decades. Their whole family is specialized in it. This means when the government passes this policy, they will fear for their existence even if the government promises unemployment benefits or other compensation. First, people are often mistrustful of politicians and promises because they are rarely keep them. Second, also they cannot imagine how else the government could get money if not through tourism. This leads to people behaving extremely risk-averse, and they will only spend money on their very basic necessaries because they are saving money for hard times to come. This includes additional education. So note that the basic for economic growth is that people are willing to spend money on goods and services.
